Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XM9-T0H1-JD6R-T25V-00000-00Steam ships and deadly viruses (a love story)2019-11-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisSteam ships and deadly viruses (a love story)CrikeyABSTRACT

This week on Side View: the myth of the white working class, no(bel) idea about genocide, climate change and insurance, and how the Don Corleone killed the Duke.

FULL TEXT

VIRULENT CARGO

Steamships are the greatest thing ever invented - if you're a deadly virus. Elsewhere, thomas Jessen Adams explores what   Cameron Hayes' workThe Fight Between Moomba and Lent says about globalisation.

How to model civilizational collapse: some advocates of climate action talk in apocalyptic terms, but other experts insist it's not too late. How do you rigorously assess their claims? Current commitments to reduce emissions aren't enough - and   electric cars are unlikely to save us, new modelling shows.

ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND MOBSTER VIOLENCE

Deleuze Indemnity: James Gunn, French philosophy and the crime novel. I found The Irishman a bit slow when Pacino wasn't on screen, but   this makes the case for it as a triumphant addition to the pantheon of "late films".

Despite the rise of the gangster movie in the 1930s, Westerns were Hollywood's staple fare right into the 1960s. Then The Godfather - it's fifty years since the novel was published - arrived and changed cinema.

By the way people forget that no one had made a decent mafia film before Godfather, and Coppola only got the gig because more prominent directors passed on what looked like another    The Brotherhood or   Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight - also a 1969 Mafia novel made into a failed film (though it had a certain actor in common with the Coppola films).

TRUMP AND OTHER MALIGN ACTORS

Trump has credibly been accused of rape. Why isn't that the basis for impeachment? Trump literally   doesn't understand how time works; bemused onlookers resort to flattering him.

Pertinent to the 2016 and 2020 elections: ahistory of how memes became weaponised. Sacha Baron Cohen is wrong -   really wrong - about tech regulation. Here's an important point that's been lost in the debate about regulation of Big Tech: the   current tech giants may actually welcome regulation because it will lock them into dominance as incumbents and make it harder for new entrants to challenge them (this explains why Australia's tech incumbents were happy to sign up to the Howard government's "critical infrastructure" security theatre).

And to another, much better-impeached president - this is really eerie: a deepfake of the speech Nixon would have given if the moon landing had gone wrong (the text of William Safire's full speech is   here).

POLITICAL DANCE CONTESTS

Darren O'Donovan is scathing about the government's handling - and attempts to duck responsibility for - the robodebt scandal ("grading political dance contests" is about an accurate description of 50-60% of Press Gallery coverage as it gets). Capital and capital cities: Claire Collie offers   an outsider's perspective on how our cities are changing. And Erin Stewart on   chronic illness, celebrity and medical ignorance.

AROUND THE WORLDNobel laureate Peter Handke (Image: Wikimedia)

The Swedish Academy has gone into full genocide denialist mode in its defence of 2019 literature laureate Peter Handke. Japan faces a   massive infrastructure maintenance bill in coming years - as it population declines and basic services close.

Loaded question alert: The Crown is conservative propaganda about white privilege - so why do feminists like it so much? The   idea of the white working class in the US electorate is a myth, argues Adam Theron-Lee Rensch.

The US Air Force is running out of spare parts to keep its Super Hornets in the air, and is cannibalising old planes. And the F-35 is a cause - is there nothing it can't mess up?

ECONOMICS

What should we actually measure for economic output? How has the finance sector damaged the global economy? And why is there growing evidence that public sectors perform better than private industry? A 2018 book describes a derailed western economy in vivid detail.

How financial fragility will be a key driver in the next generation of financial services. This is an issue to keep watching because it's only going to get worse - it's already playing out here with northern Australia becoming uninsurable and the government considering getting taxpayers to subsidise it: how climate change is   driving up insurance premiums in key markets in the United States.

Fortune recently looked at the impact on global reinsurer Swiss Re; a new report goes deeper into   US impacts.

FINALLY

A new theory suggests dogs and homo sapiens shared a key evolutionary trait that saw them win out over rival species.

(OK here's a quick one)

FULL TEXT

VIRULENT CARGO

Steamships are the greatest thing ever invented - if you're a deadly virus. Elsewhere, thomas Jessen Adams explores what   Cameron Hayes' workThe Fight Between Moomba and Lent says about globalisation.

How to model civilizational collapse: some advocates of climate action talk in apocalyptic terms, but other experts insist it's not too late. How do you rigorously assess their claims? Current commitments to reduce emissions aren't enough - and   electric cars are unlikely to save us, new modelling shows.

ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT AND MOBSTER VIOLENCE

urn:contentItem:5XGT-WD71-F19Y-C15P-00000-00Steely tariff lessons; investors' recession-proof darling; Japan's loan slowdown2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisExclusiveSteely tariff lessons; investors' recession-proof darling; Japan's loan slowdownMatthew Brown

Topics featured in this week's edition include AstraZeneca's China plans, lobbying expenditures of major tech companies and tariff lessons in the U.S. steel industry

In this edition of Weekly News Spotlight, we look at the travails of the U.S. steel industry since being hit with a tariff hike in 2018 and what it tells us about the "weaponization" of trade, and we explore whether the recent easing of U.S.-China tariff tensions provides any relief for global businesses. Meanwhile, we show why trade finance funds are increasingly popular with institutional investors.

TRADE IN FOCUS

The lesson from Trump's steel tariffs? Short-term gain but long-term pain

U.S. President Donald Trump's experiment with tariffs on steel imports has led to a boom and bust in prices and worsened overcapacity.

Analysts skeptical US-China tariff rollback will lead to lasting trade peace

A deal announced by China for it and the U.S. to roll back tariffs on each other's goods may not inspire hope that the trade dispute between the two nations will end soon and underscored that further talks can be expected.

DEEP DIVES

In-depth features looking at the impact of major news developments in key industries.

Global markets

Healthcare stocks led a record-setting S&P 500 in October as earnings surprised

Healthcare stocks dominated the list of S&P 500 top performers in October, while the index overall increased returns by 2.2% as the S&P 500 reached a new record high.

Trade finance funds grow as investors seek 'recession-proof' asset class

Banks' retreat from trade finance opens up the space for alternative financiers willing to meet demands from interested institutional investors.

Formal guidance on bank-fintech partnerships is coming, FDIC's McWilliams says

There is a pressing need for formal guidance on bank-fintech partnerships, and an interagency framework could be released by the end of 2019, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chair Jelena McWilliams said in an interview.

Digital lending still an investor magnet, but payments is catching up

Though digital lending was still the best-funded U.S. fintech subsector through the first nine months of 2019, payments had a big September.

Big-deal spigot slows to a drip in Q3

Large initial public offerings and M&A announcements highlighted the second-quarter deal-making landscape, but that was not the case in the third quarter, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence's latest M&A and Equity Offerings Market Report.

Insurance

$1.3B deal makes Liberty Mutual Berkshire's 2nd-largest retro reinsurance cedant

A third active adverse development cover between Liberty Mutual and National Indemnity involves various U.S. casualty liabilities, including certain commercial auto, workers' comp and general liability exposures.

Energy and Utilities

Legal loophole could give gas 'crucial role' in California's decarbonized grid

California will be largely relying on new renewable energy and energy storage facilities to meet its carbon neutrality goal. But natural gas generation will still have a role to play in the state's plan to move away from fossil fuels.

Lack of willing insurers leaves floating solar in US marooned for now

A lack of willing insurers is threatening to leave the nascent floating solar industry in the U.S. high and dry. Speakers at a recent conference explained what that means for innovation and growth for the market.

Consumer

McDonald's CEO change comes amid technology, menu challenges

The fast-food giant's decision to replace its CEO comes as McDonald's navigates challenges including new technology, fierce menu competition and maintaining positive relationships with franchisees.

Technology, Media and Telecommunications

Fitbit a 'natural fit' for Google, though privacy concerns remain

Fitbit Inc. could help Google LLC in its effort to expand into the wearables market, but lawmakers voiced their concerns about the deal amid the regulatory scrutiny that the Alphabet Inc. unit is facing over potential privacy and antitrust violations.

Healthcare

China's CanSino Biologics eyes increasing access of its Ebola vaccine in Africa

The Tianjin, China-based company is looking to expand the use of the vaccine in disease outbreak areas in affected parts of Africa, CEO Yu Xuefeng said.

AstraZeneca to accelerate drug launches in China as approval times get shorter

AstraZeneca PLC plans to unveil new medicines and invest in life science startups in China as policy changes create growth opportunities in the country.

M&A NEWS OF THE WEEK

First Horizon/IBERIABANK merger creates another Southeast superregional

Facing market shift, Pattern Energy sees 'certain value' in takeover bid

After closing Worldpay merger, FIS sets sights on Brazil

Post-separation, Nielsen eyes growth for consumer media, enterprise businesses

THE BIG NUMBER

Pace of lending slackens for Japanese banks amid easing hopes

Japanese banks experienced a slowdown in their lending operations as they take a cautious stance amid macroeconomic uncertainties.

TRENDING

Amazon, Facebook lead lobbying spending as big tech scrutiny grows

Major tech companies double down on their lobbying expenditures amid increased regulatory scrutiny.

Weekly News Spotlight is a newsletter published every Monday that highlights exclusive industry-focused reporting, market news, and economic insights from the global newsroom here at S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Sign up here to receive Weekly News Spotlight via email every Monday.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R47-JC71-JDPT-T32Y-00000-00STEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING ECONOMICS2017-12-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisSTEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING ECONOMICS

December 5, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

STEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS,

FERRO: Joining me around the table, Jonathan Golub, Credit Suisse Chief U.S. Equity Strategist and Stephen Auth, Federated CIO.

Guys, great to have you with me on the program. Jon, let's talk about it, what is meant to be the most efficient discounting machine on the planet has suddenly woken up and realized some tax cuts are coming. Am I really meant to believe that's what's happening?

GOLUB: Well what happened was up until probably the very last minute, everyone was focused on are we going to get something, what's going to be in it, what's it going to look like?

And all of a sudden now the question is, what does it mean for every single company separately and there's this massive readjustment on asset values that's happening.

FERRO: So what does it mean? What's the kind of research you've been doing in the last couple of weeks?

GOLUB: Well what you're seeing is is that the market is making a very crude initial attempt to figure out who are the very big winners which would be companies that are mostly domestically oriented like banks and transports and retailers, and companies that are more global in nature that are able to kind of lower their tax rate or shield it abroad like tech companies.

And it's literally just rotating from those companies like tech into some of those other natures.

FERRO: It all looked calm yesterday on the S&P500, it must have missed its rotation that was taking place beneath it. And Steve, we can take a look at the chart, the (INAUDIBLE) courtesy of Goldman Sachs.

The high tax stocks and the low tax stocks and it's a pivot away from low tax and a pivot towards high tax. It's starting to pick up. Does this have similar longevity Steve? Some room to run?

AUTH: We do. We think so Jonathan. We've been -- our last equities back in September we added to small CAP value stocks probably because we thought the tax bill would be going through.

The market has been a rotational market for the last 18 months and people forget that financials had a big run right after the president was elected. Then we took a rest, techs led. I think it's very naturally the tech stocks are a little stretched.

We still like them here. Google and Facebook are trading at 21 times in next year's earnings in these numbers. So I didn't think this correction will last forever on the tech but certainly the big beneficiaries of the tax bill if you factor in the better growth, the steeper yield curve that we think we get, and certainly lower taxes, really financials, the cyclicals, so.

FERRO: Steve, something I'm trying to get my head around is whether this is a switch from low tax to high tax or high tax to low tax or from growth to value. Is it the former or the latter or is it a mixed of these two things?

AUTH: I think there's a few trends going on here but certainly our view is there is going to be a shift to value at least the first half of next year.

You're going to have -- the economy has put in two, three percent in quarters, people have thought that it couldn't happen, we've heard that all year long, people have the wrong framework. Now we have a three percent quarter in Q4 and the tax bill, just listening to the commentary Jonathan, people just have the wrong framework on this tax bill.

FERRO: Well how does this working out then? What are they doing wrong?

AUTH: It's this Keynesian idea we've had 30 years of nothing but Keynesian economics in tax bill. So the way we analyze tax bills is, we go around and we try to figure out how many dollars each person got, we added it all up, and we say that's the stimulus for the next three weeks and we go back.

FERRO: So what should we be doing?

AUTH: This is a supply-driven tax bill. It's improving the long-term after tax returns on investment. It is going to change the productivity profile of the economy and it should overtime improve corporate investment because the after tax returns on investment have just gone up.

So we see this as it's not about how much stimulus we get next year from a dollar's perspective, maybe from a confidence perspective, and maybe from an investment perspective. I think people just have the wrong framework on this bill.

FERRO: Do you believe Jonathan Golub that we move away from capital returns and move towards capital spending and that's fueled by this tax bill?

GOLUB: You know, it's -- Steve and I have had this conversation and in all honesty, Steve was right, I didn't think the thing was good policy, I still question that. I didn't think it would get through and if it was, it's quickly and Steve was right. And that --

AUTH: Yes. Was it pulled back?

GOLUB: On the other --

AUTH: I was pulling back to your third line of defense.

GOLUB: On the other hand, do I think that the big win here is that on average, company's EPS was going to adjust something like 10 percent whenever this hits, whether it's in 2018 or in 2019.

Yes. So I think that that will dwarf the economic impact of 20 or 30 or 40 basis points, whatever the economic growth, I do. And companies have been able borrow at really low cost of capital and have not done infrastructure spending when capital was relatively free.

So I'm a little bit skeptical, not that there won't be any response but that is going to be a big overwhelming response.

AUTH: Right. The 150 in earnings, I think that's where you're heading for next year, right?

GOLUB: Well -- I mean consensus is right, if this hit in 2018 and we don't think it will but we have $146 as a consensus view, that goes to about --

AUTH: But $150 --

GOLUB: Because of that $160.

AUTH: Yes.

GOLUB: OK. And so -- now -- but it's not --

AUTH: But this is the owe it moment for much of Wall Street right now all year long. And we've done this on this show Jonathan, people have been fighting about -- they just assume it's a fact the market is expensive.

It's just been assumed fact. They're looking at the valuation on the market relative to a recession earnings number in 2016, earnings recession, 115. And the owe it moment is we're here three weeks from the end of the year and we're talking about, is the earnings number for next year $150 or $160? That's 16 to 17 time multiple on a market that we were told is trading mid 20s.

FERRO: So we're trading at 18 times forward --

GOLUB: But there is a different story --

AUTH: Exactly. Well this market (INAUDIBLE) cheap but the market is not expensive and everyone that's been telling their client said it is is literally now trying to back away from this position gently.

GOLUB: Yes. And what you also know is I've been quite bullish on the market and I don't think the market has been --

AUTH: You've been dead writing on the market Jonathan just so you --

GOLUB: Right. You're throwing me --

AUTH: We can do something, I appreciate that. I'm -- and you've been consistently bullish on the market largely on your earnings (INAUDIBLE) which have been good. But my point is you're now upgrading it to $150, $160, you got to be --

GOLUB: Yes. Or when -- and you have to wait for the exact details to come up. But if something, it has to move on that. So the question which we don't know is if let's say earnings were to go up.

And that the question which we don't know is if let's say earnings were to go up, let's just say 10 percent, I don't know what the number is. Does the market say, I give you 10 percent extra price? Does it say, it's a lower quality benefit because it's taxes and it give you 5?

Is Steve Auth right? And you say, you get that plus the potential for more efficiency and you get 15?

AUTH: Right. And that's the opportunity, that's the debate now because that bears on the thing happening, they're falling back to, "Oh, this is a kind of short-term stimulus, long-term," no difference.

Where we're different at Federated is we believe this actually makes the economy more productive in a higher growth trajectory over the next three to five years. And on that basis, it's not just the one auth hit to earnings but it puts us on a more stable platform.

It keeps the Fed at bay because of the productivity impacting inflation and you've got a pretty healthy environment for stocks.

GOLUB: Is the Fed (INAUDIBLE)

AUTH: We're talking value stocks.

GOLUB: Well I don't think there's a bear case on this. I think the question is, is this bullish for the market or is this really, really bullish for the market? And I'm kind of -- and so the question is, does this set off another wave of spending?

Does this ultimately -- I mean, what we know is this will increase deficits. I mean, that's -- there's always the commerce that's telling you that this is a $1 billion to $1.5 billion (INAUDIBLE)

FERRO: They're telling you -- you know it's going to increase deficits.

GOLUB: Well this engage the Fed to be a little bit more aggressive because the labor market's already tied and it squeezes.

I mean, when I look at market behavior, the most important thing is that the recovery just keeps going. If this shortens the recovery by pulling the Fed even six months earlier, that may undo some of the benefit here.

And that's perhaps where you and I are -- there's no question on the basic math. The question is, second order effect, not going to affect the --

AUTH: Productivity in the longer term growth impact.

GOLUB: I'm skeptical.

AUTH: Yes.

GOLUB: And you know what, I rather be skeptical and be right later. But --

FERRO: You know why Steve feels so good? He's been right for the most of the last 12 months. Look at him he's smiling at your end.

AUTH: There are times when I'm wrong.

FERRO: Yes, right. Jonathan Golub at Credit Suisse sticking with us. Steve Auth of federated staying with us as well.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FERRO: I want to bring in Steve Auth. Steve, are you comfortable? Still bullish going into next year if the Deutsche Bank will prove correct for hikes?

AUTH: Oh no, they're right. I would be much more cautious on the market, yes.

AUTH: Yes. But I don't think they're right. But --

FERRO: Why don't you think they're right?

AUTH: I think they have the wrong framework again. The Fed -- first of all, you can't say this bill is at one hand not going to stimulate that much and then turn around later and say it's going to cost the Fed to panic. So in the near-term, there isn't a lot of extra spending unleashed by the bill.

FERRO: Is four hikes a panic?

AUTH: Four hikes is a lot more than the market expects. At Federated we're thinking we get December, we get maybe one or two hikes next year and the primary way of the Fed tightening from here is QT, reversing QE basically.

And maybe they accelerate that path which actually would steepen the yield curve which, again, would be good for the financial. So this is a little contrarian to where the market is. A market is into this idea that the yield curve is going to continue to flatten. And, yes, I think that's bad for the equity market, and Brett's right.

FERRO: So let's play this out, Brett's on the phone, Brett gets you call he says four next year, what would you say back to him?

AUTH: I say, Brett, I disagree with you, I just don't see it. What Brett is depending on I believe and I would ask him, "Brett, what are you depending on?" And he would say he's depending on inflation picking up.

FERRO: Are you dependent on that Brett?

RYAN: That is one of the key (INAUDIBLE) I mean the Fed's credibility is, of course, with an inflation. I would say listen, these are valid points and one thing I would say is that we've been in this sort of market where they're reluctant to press much beyond the next six months in this environment.

And I don't exactly know why. I don't think that that's going to change its balance sheet policy but I think there's a valid point about the steeping of the curve as we get more details out of the ECD and potentially some action further down the line with the BOJ. So there are certainly risks and very valid points, understood.

GOLUB: In order to get four next year, the Fed needs to move market participants along that path which means they need to basically start screaming fire right now that we have an inflation problem. It doesn't mean that if you --

FERRO: Pretty difficult to scream fire when there's hardly any smoke.

AUTH: There's no inflation problem. We've got all these deflationary forces out there --

GOLUB: And so I'm say, to get from here to four that means they have to start basically getting the market convinced that this is happening right away. Which means they are going to -- they're going to knowingly smash the yield curve and assume that equity investors aren't going to -- you look at that as a sign to panic.

And I think that they're going to drive the -- if they do what's being laid out here, they are knowingly telling the equity market that it's -- that the party is over and I just don't think the Fed would do that unless you have a real steepening of the yield curve and really truly visible inflation which may happen. But until we actually see that, I think that this kind of call is -- would be startling.

FERRO: Well in fairness, let's give the final word to Brett Ryan. Brett, is there going to be a communication problems to achieve the kind of hikes at a kind of velocity that you think they're going to be up to deliver the map?

RYAN: Well -- I mean, let's look what happened over the past year, the market had nothing prices in for dealing of this year (INAUDIBLE) three times and surprise the market a bit and stock markets have gone up.

I think the last I've said is that even like what the Fed's framework is, they see neutral to eight and they don't see this as a necessarily tightening stance in a sense that it's pushing back against growth.

They see this as being a prudent move to get to neutral. And to your point about the stock market, they're looking at financial conditions and they're obviously factoring in the fact that financial conditions continue to ease even though they keep tightening.

And it's starting to at least bother them a little bit and make them a little concern. So maybe it's less about the inflation picture and more about financial stability which they're taking into account.

FERRO: All right Brett, really appreciate your time sir to join us. Brett Ryan of Deutche Bank, thank you. Jonathan Golub of Credit Suisse and Steve Auth of Federated will be sticking with us up.

FERRO: Mark Yusko joining the team around the table in New York, Morgan Creek Capital Founder and CIO. Mark, 400k, I think it's fair to say the experts on Bitcoin and not on Wall Street, they're elsewhere because pretty much everyone I've spoken to so far says the following.

YUSKO: Well but the problem is Bitcoin is a block chain, right? It is a block chain. So it is a form of this revolutionary disruptive technology.

If you and I exchange currency or CAP commerce using Bitcoin and it goes on the ledger on the block chain, we don't need a bank to confirm that that is a valid transaction. So it has the potential to disrupt banking as we know it.

FERRO: How do we get to 400l?

YUSKO: So 400k is very simple, it's just math, right? It is gold equivalence. So there are 21 million Bitcoin total. No, actually it won't be 21 million because a few have been destroyed. So call it 20 million-ish.

And the reason that's so interesting for a gold equivalent is think about gold, all of it in the world fits into an Olympic-size swimming pool. It's very heavy, if I have a bar, it's really hard for me to give everybody a piece.

FERRO: I can't even afford a single piece of Bitcoin, never mind a bar of gold, we're not even there yet. Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek is going to be sticking with us.

FERRO: Around the table with me to strip back this open is Jonathan Golub of Credit Suisse, Steve Auth of Federated and Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek. Mark, is this still the most hated bull market ever?

AUTH: Oh, it's completely unloved. It's been an unloved rally all the way up. That's what creates 20-year bull markets which is what we're in.

YUSKO: Wait a second, how do you say there are people on investment? We have the highest waiting -- the individual investor has the highest waiting in equities in history, we have the lowest cash holdings in mutual funds since 2000. How do you say it's unloved?

AUTH: First of all, it is unloved based on how -- what allocations are to equities unless where you're getting numbers from. And I don't know what kind of flows you're looking at but flows in equities over the last five or six years have been basically constantly selling net sales of equity funds.

Jonathan and I were just at a dinner last night with a bunch of investors, very typical, the kind of things I see, people are cautious. They've been cautious all the way up because they think even if they acknowledge that, "OK, maybe we get another pop here" and then it's going to heck in a hand basket to use an old expression.

YUSKO: Yes.

AUTH: And it's that fear that keeps the markets at a reasonable level. The goldilocks situation we have around us.

FERRO: Jon, you want to weigh in?

GOLUB: You know, markets don't move up because of sentiment because you like it and he doesn't. They move up because -- I mean there's really two things that matter, is the economic expansion going to continue for the next year or two or longer? Yes.

Our company's generating positive cash flows and I'll take a swipe but at the -- relative to Bitcoin which it doesn't create cash flows but nonetheless, do as big companies spit off a boatload of cash.

Yes, if you look in the last 10 years while the economy has been weaker, companies have generated twice the cash flow for dollar or sales than they have historically. That directly translates into what you call expensive but I would call is justifiable above average valuations.

FERRO: So about three, four minutes into the open guys, I just want to get up to the -- up the scores on the screen.

Jon, you think this has got legs, don't you?

GOLUB: Every single stock has to be revalued right now because there's a new tax rate that gets applied to their earnings. We know that tech is a low tax rate sector, we know that you're talking about an alternative, minimum tax for corporations which is going to make it a little expensive.

And so there's an adjustment going on until the market thinks that they're done in getting everything to fair value which we're probably 60 percent through or something. We're going to see rotation.

People are not selling or buying the market, they're simply trying to realign their portfolios in order to figure out what fair value is.

FERRO: What are your thoughts on tech Mark because it can't just be about technology and tax pure and simple? These are the companies that generate tremendous earnings growth, revenue growth for 2017 as well.

YUSKO: And actually what's happening this week really has nothing to do with taxes and has nothing to do with tech selling.

FERRO: Tell us what's going on?

YUSKO: It's a big hedge fund unwinding with big leverage.

FERRO: OK.

YUSKO: But they're having to unwind a very large tech book, they run a lot of leverage. And there are these platform funds out there and they use a lot of managers and they all individual mangers run market neutral. Equal dollar, long dollar short, then the fund puts big leverage on top of it.

Five, six, eight, ten times leverage. When that turns and they got caught, OK, long tech and short the consumer and the media names and that's going the wrong way. So they're losing on both sides, they have to de-risk and --

AUTH: But their pain is our gain. I mean we've got the S&P at 3,000 for next year and what I like about it is you can certainly look at the financials. Take at J.P. Morgan, it's trading, it's got maybe $10.00 in earnings next year with this tax bill, it's trading at $1.06.

That is not expensive, that's like an 11 multiple. Yet in this correction, Facebook today is trading I think at 20 times next year as earnings. These are big growth companies. I do think that tech --

YUSKO: Well Facebook is (INAUDIBLE) 15 percent.

AUTH: Exactly. But, OK, it's currently pushed these big tech stocks a little lower, technical reasons, they unwind. I think it's going to end up being a great opportunity. I mean, we've been buying the financials all year.

But I think -- and longer time but I would see a great opportunity here setting up to add to these big tech positions. These are winners in the global --

YUSKO: I was only talking about this week. I'm not talking about a big trend. The challenge we have is earnings and PE multiples, right? If you look earnings today or where they were on an as reported basis, not this earnings before bad stuff pro forma garbage.

But the actual earnings of the S&P are the same as they were five years ago yet the market is 80 percent higher, that's all multiples --

GOLUB: Well wait, that's not a fair share. First of all, you had oil prices adjust massively. If you take out the earnings in the energy sector, the earnings have --

YUSKO: Yes, so that's what I'm trying --

GOLUB: But, of course, but as soon as take out --

YUSKO: I'm not talking about 2009 to 2012. I'm talking about the last five years, 2012 to 2017, the earnings --

YUSKO: Oil peaked 2014. Oil peaked at 2014. I'm talking about since 2012 to 2017, oil prices are lower certainly but you can't take out one sector. That's like saying, I would be six foot four if I had former --

AUTH: That's what makes the market. It could have people that are --

FERRO: I want to take out one (INAUDIBLE) Gerard Cassidy, obviously Capital Markets Managing Director on his rotation into the financial. Gerard, for a lot of people out there that have seen this run out (INAUDIBLE) in the last couple weeks and say, "Am I too late?" What do you say back to them?

CASSIDY: I would say no. When we look at the banks we are still seeing expectations for a higher interest rates and the higher interest rates will lead to better profitability for the sector.

And the tax rate cuts are obviously important but the bigger impact for the banks is the expected growth that's coming from tax reform and that will lead to stronger loan growth on top of higher interest rates. So you're still going to --

FERRO: Gerard, the pushback -- the pushback sir is that the demand might not be there on the consumer and the business side but the loan growth might be available, the supply might be ther ready to go but no one wants to borrow. Do you see that changing because at the moment in the data, it looks a little softer?

CASSIDY: You're right. The data certainly is specifically in commercial lending but when you look at commercial real estate and you look at the consumer side, we're seeing mid single digital growth.

So if real GDP is going to accelerate next year, that should drive commercial loan growth stronger than it is today.

FERRO: Mark Yusko?

YUSKO: But Gerard, how does GDP accelerate next year? One thing we know is that deficits and debt actually crowd out and lower economic growth. So it's likely the economic growth goes lower.

GDP -- nominal GDP growth is equal to working in population growth plus productivity, both of which are sub one percent. So I don't know how we get this big boom in economic growth and the CNI data says that loans are softening, credit card delinquencies are rising?

Loan payment -- student loan delinquencies are over one-third today, how is that positive for banks?

CASSIDY: I would say first on the student loan side, that's us as taxpayers, the banks have nothing to do with the student lending, that's all U.S. government. So for the banks, that's an issue.

But delinquencies on credit cards, you got to remember we were at all time record lows two years ago and we're still at unusually low level. So the credit card delinquencies doesn't -- don't really concern us unless unemployment starts to rise.

But when you look at the Kennedy tax cuts and the Reagan tax cuts, both of those time periods within four quarters of the tax cuts, the economy in those time periods accelerated and, of course, in the Reagan cuts, you remember all the deficits and the concerns about deficits crowding out borrowers and it didn't happen and it doesn't appear to be (INAUDIBLE) today.

So as more people have money to spend as well as corporate, traditionally, again, using the history as a guide, we would suggest we're going to see an accelerated GDP number when this kicks in.

FERRO: Jonathan Golub, before we lose you, Deutsche Bank was on this program 20 minutes ago talking about four rate hikes. We were talking about anticipating a flatter yield curve. What does that mean for financials four rate hike next year, the potential for even flatter yield curve?

But the conditions that you would have for rate hikes would probably mean that we got much more economic flow through the tax plan. The yield curve is ripping at the long end of the curve and the market may be looking at this thing thinking, "Gosh, things are almost too good."

But the Fed's not doing four rate hikes next year unless conditions are that good.

AMOBI: No question this administration is more inclined to a rollback of media regulations that will provide we think a catalyst.

urn:contentItem:5R43-WHB1-JB20-G16M-00000-00Stephen Auth is interviewed on BB TV.2017-12-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTStephen Auth, Tuna Amobi, Gerard Cassidy, Mark Yusko, Jonathan Golub, Brett RyanNEWSInternational120584cb.550Stephen Auth is interviewed on BB TV.Jonathan Ferro

Stephen Auth discusses economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

STEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

DECEMBER 05, 2017

SPEAKERS: STEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS

TUNA AMOBI, CONSUMER CYCLICAL ANALYST, CFRA RESEARCH

GERARD CASSIDY, MANAGING DIRECTOR, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS

MARK YUSKO, FOUNDER, CEO AND CIO, MORGAN CREEK CAPITAL

JONATHAN GOLUB, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, CREDIT SUISSE

BRETT RYAN, U.S. ECONOMIST, DEUTSCHE BANK

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining me around the table, Jonathan Golub, Credit Suisse Chief U.S. Equity Strategist and Stephen Auth, Federated CIO.

Guys, great to have you with me on the program. Jon, let's talk about it, what is meant to be the most efficient discounting machine on the planet has suddenly woken up and realized some tax cuts are coming. Am I really meant to believe that's what's happening?

JONATHAN GOLUB, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, CREDIT SUISSE: Well what happened was up until probably the very last minute, everyone was focused on are we going to get something, what's going to be in it, what's it going to look like?

And all of a sudden now the question is, what does it mean for every single company separately and there's this massive readjustment on asset values that's happening.

FERRO: So what does it mean? What's the kind of research you've been doing in the last couple of weeks?

GOLUB: Well what you're seeing is is that the market is making a very crude initial attempt to figure out who are the very big winners which would be companies that are mostly domestically oriented like banks and transports and retailers, and companies that are more global in nature that are able to kind of lower their tax rate or shield it abroad like tech companies.

And it's literally just rotating from those companies like tech into some of those other natures.

FERRO: It all looked calm yesterday on the S&P500, it must have missed its rotation that was taking place beneath it. And Steve, we can take a look at the chart, the (INAUDIBLE) courtesy of Goldman Sachs.

The high tax stocks and the low tax stocks and it's a pivot away from low tax and a pivot towards high tax. It's starting to pick up. Does this have similar longevity Steve? Some room to run?

STEPHEN AUTH, CIO OF GLOBAL EQUITY, FEDERATED INVESTORS: We do. We think so Jonathan. We've been -- our last equities back in September we added to small CAP value stocks probably because we thought the tax bill would be going through.

The market has been a rotational market for the last 18 months and people forget that financials had a big run right after the president was elected. Then we took a rest, techs led. I think it's very naturally the tech stocks are a little stretched.

We still like them here. Google and Facebook are trading at 21 times in next year's earnings in these numbers. So I didn't think this correction will last forever on the tech but certainly the big beneficiaries of the tax bill if you factor in the better growth, the steeper yield curve that we think we get, and certainly lower taxes, really financials, the cyclicals, so.

FERRO: Steve, something I'm trying to get my head around is whether this is a switch from low tax to high tax or high tax to low tax or from growth to value. Is it the former or the latter or is it a mixed of these two things?

AUTH: I think there's a few trends going on here but certainly our view is there is going to be a shift to value at least the first half of next year.

You're going to have -- the economy has put in two, three percent in quarters, people have thought that it couldn't happen, we've heard that all year long, people have the wrong framework. Now we have a three percent quarter in Q4 and the tax bill, just listening to the commentary Jonathan, people just have the wrong framework on this tax bill.

FERRO: Well how does this working out then? What are they doing wrong?

AUTH: It's this Keynesian idea we've had 30 years of nothing but Keynesian economics in tax bill. So the way we analyze tax bills is, we go around and we try to figure out how many dollars each person got, we added it all up, and we say that's the stimulus for the next three weeks and we go back.

FERRO: So what should we be doing?

AUTH: This is a supply-driven tax bill. It's improving the long-term after tax returns on investment. It is going to change the productivity profile of the economy and it should overtime improve corporate investment because the after tax returns on investment have just gone up.

So we see this as it's not about how much stimulus we get next year from a dollar's perspective, maybe from a confidence perspective, and maybe from an investment perspective. I think people just have the wrong framework on this bill.

FERRO: Do you believe Jonathan Golub that we move away from capital returns and move towards capital spending and that's fueled by this tax bill?

GOLUB: You know, it's -- Steve and I have had this conversation and in all honesty, Steve was right, I didn't think the thing was good policy, I still question that. I didn't think it would get through and if it was, it's quickly and Steve was right. And that --

AUTH: Yes. Was it pulled back?

GOLUB: On the other --

AUTH: I was pulling back to your third line of defense.

GOLUB: On the other hand, do I think that the big win here is that on average, company's EPS was going to adjust something like 10 percent whenever this hits, whether it's in 2018 or in 2019.

Yes. So I think that that will dwarf the economic impact of 20 or 30 or 40 basis points, whatever the economic growth, I do. And companies have been able borrow at really low cost of capital and have not done infrastructure spending when capital was relatively free.

So I'm a little bit skeptical, not that there won't be any response but that is going to be a big overwhelming response.

AUTH: Right. The 150 in earnings, I think that's where you're heading for next year, right?

GOLUB: Well -- I mean consensus is right, if this hit in 2018 and we don't think it will but we have $146 as a consensus view, that goes to about --

AUTH: But $150 --

GOLUB: Because of that $160.

AUTH: Yes.

GOLUB: OK. And so -- now -- but it's not --

AUTH: But this is the owe it moment for much of Wall Street right now all year long. And we've done this on this show Jonathan, people have been fighting about -- they just assume it's a fact the market is expensive.

It's just been assumed fact. They're looking at the valuation on the market relative to a recession earnings number in 2016, earnings recession, 115. And the owe it moment is we're here three weeks from the end of the year and we're talking about, is the earnings number for next year $150 or $160? That's 16 to 17 time multiple on a market that we were told is trading mid 20s.

FERRO: So we're trading at 18 times forward --

GOLUB: But there is a different story --

AUTH: Exactly. Well this market (INAUDIBLE) cheap but the market is not expensive and everyone that's been telling their client said it is is literally now trying to back away from this position gently.

GOLUB: Yes. And what you also know is I've been quite bullish on the market and I don't think the market has been --

AUTH: You've been dead writing on the market Jonathan just so you --

GOLUB: Right. You're throwing me --

AUTH: We can do something, I appreciate that. I'm -- and you've been consistently bullish on the market largely on your earnings (INAUDIBLE) which have been good. But my point is you're now upgrading it to $150, $160, you got to be --

GOLUB: Yes. Or when -- and you have to wait for the exact details to come up. But if something, it has to move on that. So the question which we don't know is if let's say earnings were to go up.

And that the question which we don't know is if let's say earnings were to go up, let's just say 10 percent, I don't know what the number is. Does the market say, I give you 10 percent extra price? Does it say, it's a lower quality benefit because it's taxes and it give you 5?

Is Steve Auth right? And you say, you get that plus the potential for more efficiency and you get 15?

AUTH: Right. And that's the opportunity, that's the debate now because that bears on the thing happening, they're falling back to, "Oh, this is a kind of short-term stimulus, long-term," no difference.

Where we're different at Federated is we believe this actually makes the economy more productive in a higher growth trajectory over the next three to five years. And on that basis, it's not just the one auth hit to earnings but it puts us on a more stable platform.

It keeps the Fed at bay because of the productivity impacting inflation and you've got a pretty healthy environment for stocks.

GOLUB: Is the Fed (INAUDIBLE)

AUTH: We're talking value stocks.

GOLUB: Well I don't think there's a bear case on this. I think the question is, is this bullish for the market or is this really, really bullish for the market? And I'm kind of -- and so the question is, does this set off another wave of spending?

Does this ultimately -- I mean, what we know is this will increase deficits. I mean, that's -- there's always the commerce that's telling you that this is a $1 billion to $1.5 billion (INAUDIBLE)

FERRO: They're telling you -- you know it's going to increase deficits.

GOLUB: Well this engage the Fed to be a little bit more aggressive because the labor market's already tied and it squeezes.

I mean, when I look at market behavior, the most important thing is that the recovery just keeps going. If this shortens the recovery by pulling the Fed even six months earlier, that may undo some of the benefit here.

And that's perhaps where you and I are -- there's no question on the basic math. The question is, second order effect, not going to affect the --

AUTH: Productivity in the longer term growth impact.

GOLUB: I'm skeptical.

AUTH: Yes.

GOLUB: And you know what, I rather be skeptical and be right later. But - -

FERRO: You know why Steve feels so good? He's been right for the most of the last 12 months. Look at him he's smiling at your end.

AUTH: There are times when I'm wrong.

FERRO: Yes, right. Jonathan Golub at Credit Suisse sticking with us. Steve Auth of federated staying with us as well.

FERRO: I want to bring in Steve Auth. Steve, are you comfortable? Still bullish going into next year if the Deutsche Bank will prove correct for hikes?

AUTH: Oh no, they're right. I would be much more cautious on the market, yes.

FERRO: You would think?

AUTH: Yes. But I don't think they're right. But --

FERRO: Why don't you think they're right?

AUTH: I think they have the wrong framework again. The Fed -- first of all, you can't say this bill is at one hand not going to stimulate that much and then turn around later and say it's going to cost the Fed to panic. So in the near-term, there isn't a lot of extra spending unleashed by the bill.

FERRO: Is four hikes a panic?

AUTH: Four hikes is a lot more than the market expects. At Federated we're thinking we get December, we get maybe one or two hikes next year and the primary way of the Fed tightening from here is QT, reversing QE basically.

And maybe they accelerate that path which actually would steepen the yield curve which, again, would be good for the financial. So this is a little contrarian to where the market is. A market is into this idea that the yield curve is going to continue to flatten. And, yes, I think that's bad for the equity market, and Brett's right.

FERRO: So let's play this out, Brett's on the phone, Brett gets you call he says four next year, what would you say back to him?

AUTH: I say, Brett, I disagree with you, I just don't see it. What Brett is depending on I believe and I would ask him, "Brett, what are you depending on?" And he would say he's depending on inflation picking up.

FERRO: Are you dependent on that Brett?

BRETT RYAN, U.S. ECONOMIST, DEUTSCHE BANK: That is one of the key (INAUDIBLE) I mean the Fed's credibility is, of course, with an inflation. I would say listen, these are valid points and one thing I would say is that we've been in this sort of market where they're reluctant to press much beyond the next six months in this environment.

And I don't exactly know why. I don't think that that's going to change its balance sheet policy but I think there's a valid point about the steeping of the curve as we get more details out of the ECD and potentially some action further down the line with the BOJ. So there are certainly risks and very valid points, understood.

GOLUB: In order to get four next year, the Fed needs to move market participants along that path which means they need to basically start screaming fire right now that we have an inflation problem. It doesn't mean that if you --

FERRO: Pretty difficult to scream fire when there's hardly any smoke.

AUTH: There's no inflation problem. We've got all these deflationary forces out there --

GOLUB: And so I'm say, to get from here to four that means they have to start basically getting the market convinced that this is happening right away. Which means they are going to -- they're going to knowingly smash the yield curve and assume that equity investors aren't going to -- you look at that as a sign to panic.

And I think that they're going to drive the -- if they do what's being laid out here, they are knowingly telling the equity market that it's -- that the party is over and I just don't think the Fed would do that unless you have a real steepening of the yield curve and really truly visible inflation which may happen. But until we actually see that, I think that this kind of call is -- would be startling.

FERRO: Well in fairness, let's give the final word to Brett Ryan. Brett, is there going to be a communication problems to achieve the kind of hikes at a kind of velocity that you think they're going to be up to deliver the map?

RYAN: Well -- I mean, let's look what happened over the past year, the market had nothing prices in for dealing of this year (INAUDIBLE) three times and surprise the market a bit and stock markets have gone up.

I think the last I've said is that even like what the Fed's framework is, they see neutral to eight and they don't see this as a necessarily tightening stance in a sense that it's pushing back against growth.

They see this as being a prudent move to get to neutral. And to your point about the stock market, they're looking at financial conditions and they're obviously factoring in the fact that financial conditions continue to ease even though they keep tightening.

And it's starting to at least bother them a little bit and make them a little concern. So maybe it's less about the inflation picture and more about financial stability which they're taking into account.

FERRO: All right Brett, really appreciate your time sir to join us. Brett Ryan of Deutche Bank, thank you. Jonathan Golub of Credit Suisse and Steve Auth of Federated will be sticking with us up.

FERRO: Mark Yusko joining the team around the table in New York, Morgan Creek Capital Founder and CIO. Mark, 400k, I think it's fair to say the experts on Bitcoin and not on Wall Street, they're elsewhere because pretty much everyone I've spoken to so far says the following.

Don't know anything about it but think there's some value in block chain and that's kind of where the conversation begins and ends. For you?

MARK YUSKO, FOUNDER, CEO AND CIO, MORGAN CREEK CAPITAL: Well but the problem is Bitcoin is a block chain, right? It is a block chain. So it is a form of this revolutionary disruptive technology.

And look, all the bank, people that you showed, they should be deathly afraid of this. This displaces -- this has the potential to displace the need for banks as a trust institution. If you and I exchange currency or CAP commerce using Bitcoin and it goes on the ledger on the block chain, we don't need a bank to confirm that that is a valid transaction. So it has the potential to disrupt banking as we know it.

FERRO: How do we get to 400l?

YUSKO: So 400k is very simple, it's just math, right? It is gold equivalence. So there are 21 million Bitcoin total. No, actually it won't be 21 million because a few have been destroyed. So call it 20 million- ish.

So 20 million in gold today is about eight trillion, it gives you 400k. Now that doesn't include any use cases like currency. Like if you and I want to exchange a medium of currency, I'm just talking about gold equivalence.

And the reason that's so interesting for a gold equivalent is think about gold, all of it in the world fits into an Olympic-size swimming pool. It's very heavy, if I have a bar, it's really hard for me to give everybody a piece.

FERRO: I can't even afford a single piece of Bitcoin, never mind a bar of gold, we're not even there yet. Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek is going to be sticking with us.

FERRO: Around the table with me to strip back this open is Jonathan Golub of Credit Suisse, Steve Auth of Federated and Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek. Mark, is this still the most hated bull market ever?

YUSKO: I think that is such a ridiculous state.

FERRO: Will you tell me why because --

YUSKO: Cash --

FERRO: Wait, wait, wait, we're at record highs and no one comes on this program saying that the market is cheap, they say it's expensive. No one sits here and says this is going to last longer and say we remain defensive and then we keep grinding up to all time high. It doesn't feel (INAUDIBLE)

YUSKO: Well that's because the quality -- the host attracts quality client (INAUDIBLE) you have smart people who come on the show. And intelligent person has to look at the market and say it's expensive, you have to do that.

It doesn't mean it can't get more expensive but you can't say it's cheap. There's no definition on the planet except denominated in gold. Actually denominated in gold were lower than 2000 or lower than 2007.

But in dollars you can't say it's cheap. But what you can say is that we are in a period where there's bullions and their speculative fervor towards stocks but you can't say it's cheap.

FERRO: It still feels unloved to me Steve.

AUTH: Oh, it's completely unloved. It's been an unloved rally all the way up. That's what creates 20-year bull markets which is what we're in.

We came off 2008, 2009, everybody in the game believes we got a 40 percent down draft around the corner and that's what get people relatively light in equities, that's what kept flows out of equity funds. It's why people say it's expensive even though it isn't, you got one year --

YUSKO: Wait a second, how do you say there are people on investment? We have the highest waiting -- the individual investor has the highest waiting in equities in history, we have the lowest cash holdings in mutual funds since 2000. How do you say it's unloved?

AUTH: First of all, it is unloved based on how -- what allocations are to equities unless where you're getting numbers from. And I don't know what kind of flows you're looking at but flows in equities over the last five or six years have been basically constantly selling net sales of equity funds.

Jonathan and I were just at a dinner last night with a bunch of investors, very typical, the kind of things I see, people are cautious. They've been cautious all the way up because they think even if they acknowledge that, "OK, maybe we get another pop here" and then it's going to heck in a hand basket to use an old expression.

YUSKO: Yes.

AUTH: And it's that fear that keeps the markets at a reasonable level. The goldilocks situation we have around us.

FERRO: Jon, you want to weigh in?

GOLUB: You know, markets don't move up because of sentiment because you like it and he doesn't. They move up because -- I mean there's really two things that matter, is the economic expansion going to continue for the next year or two or longer? Yes.

Our company's generating positive cash flows and I'll take a swipe but at the -- relative to Bitcoin which it doesn't create cash flows but nonetheless, do as big companies spit off a boatload of cash.

Yes, if you look in the last 10 years while the economy has been weaker, companies have generated twice the cash flow for dollar or sales than they have historically. That directly translates into what you call expensive but I would call is justifiable above average valuations.

FERRO: So about three, four minutes into the open guys, I just want to get up to the -- up the scores on the screen.

Jon, you think this has got legs, don't you?

GOLUB: Every single stock has to be revalued right now because there's a new tax rate that gets applied to their earnings. We know that tech is a low tax rate sector, we know that you're talking about an alternative, minimum tax for corporations which is going to make it a little expensive.

And so there's an adjustment going on until the market thinks that they're done in getting everything to fair value which we're probably 60 percent through or something. We're going to see rotation.

People are not selling or buying the market, they're simply trying to realign their portfolios in order to figure out what fair value is.

FERRO: What are your thoughts on tech Mark because it can't just be about technology and tax pure and simple? These are the companies that generate tremendous earnings growth, revenue growth for 2017 as well.

YUSKO: And actually what's happening this week really has nothing to do with taxes and has nothing to do with tech selling.

FERRO: Tell us what's going on?

YUSKO: It's a big hedge fund unwinding with big leverage.

FERRO: What's the source for that? What are you looking at?

YUSKO: We talked -- we do a lot of work with a lot of hedge funds and there's a big hedge fund that I won't name to protect the innocent.

FERRO: OK.

YUSKO: But they're having to unwind a very large tech book, they run a lot of leverage. And there are these platform funds out there and they use a lot of managers and they all individual mangers run market neutral. Equal dollar, long dollar short, then the fund puts big leverage on top of it.

Five, six, eight, ten times leverage. When that turns and they got caught, OK, long tech and short the consumer and the media names and that's going the wrong way. So they're losing on both sides, they have to de-risk and - -

AUTH: But their pain is our gain. I mean we've got the S&P at 3,000 for next year and what I like about it is you can certainly look at the financials. Take at J.P. Morgan, it's trading, it's got maybe $10.00 in earnings next year with this tax bill, it's trading at $1.06.

That is not expensive, that's like an 11 multiple. Yet in this correction, Facebook today is trading I think at 20 times next year as earnings. These are big growth companies. I do think that tech --

YUSKO: Well Facebook is (INAUDIBLE) 15 percent.

AUTH: Exactly. But, OK, it's currently pushed these big tech stocks a little lower, technical reasons, they unwind. I think it's going to end up being a great opportunity. I mean, we've been buying the financials all year.

But I think -- and longer time but I would see a great opportunity here setting up to add to these big tech positions. These are winners in the global --

YUSKO: I was only talking about this week. I'm not talking about a big trend. The challenge we have is earnings and PE multiples, right? If you look earnings today or where they were on an as reported basis, not this earnings before bad stuff pro forma garbage.

But the actual earnings of the S&P are the same as they were five years ago yet the market is 80 percent higher, that's all multiples --

GOLUB: Well wait, that's not a fair share. First of all, you had oil prices adjust massively. If you take out the earnings in the energy sector, the earnings have --

YUSKO: Yes, so that's what I'm trying --

GOLUB: But, of course, but as soon as take out --

AUTH: Look, in 2010 the S&P earnings are $60.00, today we're talking about $150. It's been almost a three bagger. Two-thirds of the run up in the S&P and everyone here has said it's not going to happen as --

YUSKO: I'm not talking about --

AUTH: Two-thirds of a runoff off of -- run up off of 2009 has been actually --

YUSKO: I'm not talking about 2009 to 2012. I'm talking about the last five years, 2012 to 2017, the earnings --

AUTH: But your starting point is a peak dollar a price of oil.

GOLUB: But over four years when you did well at the bottom and --

YUSKO: Oil peaked 2014. Oil peaked at 2014. I'm talking about since 2012 to 2017, oil prices are lower certainly but you can't take out one sector. That's like saying, I would be six foot four if I had former --

AUTH: That's what makes the market. It could have people that are --

FERRO: I want to take out one (INAUDIBLE) Gerard Cassidy, obviously Capital Markets Managing Director on his rotation into the financial. Gerard, for a lot of people out there that have seen this run out (INAUDIBLE) in the last couple weeks and say, "Am I too late?" What do you say back to them?

GERARD CASSIDY, MANAGING DIRECTOR, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS: I would say no. When we look at the banks we are still seeing expectations for a higher interest rates and the higher interest rates will lead to better profitability for the sector.

And the tax rate cuts are obviously important but the bigger impact for the banks is the expected growth that's coming from tax reform and that will lead to stronger loan growth on top of higher interest rates. So you're still going to --

FERRO: Gerard, the pushback -- the pushback sir is that the demand might not be there on the consumer and the business side but the loan growth might be available, the supply might be ther ready to go but no one wants to borrow. Do you see that changing because at the moment in the data, it looks a little softer?

CASSIDY: You're right. The data certainly is specifically in commercial lending but when you look at commercial real estate and you look at the consumer side, we're seeing mid single digital growth.

So if real GDP is going to accelerate next year, that should drive commercial loan growth stronger than it is today.

FERRO: Mark Yusko?

YUSKO: But Gerard, how does GDP accelerate next year? One thing we know is that deficits and debt actually crowd out and lower economic growth. So it's likely the economic growth goes lower.

GDP -- nominal GDP growth is equal to working in population growth plus productivity, both of which are sub one percent. So I don't know how we get this big boom in economic growth and the CNI data says that loans are softening, credit card delinquencies are rising?

Loan payment -- student loan delinquencies are over one-third today, how is that positive for banks?

CASSIDY: I would say first on the student loan side, that's us as taxpayers, the banks have nothing to do with the student lending, that's all U.S. government. So for the banks, that's an issue.

But delinquencies on credit cards, you got to remember we were at all time record lows two years ago and we're still at unusually low level. So the credit card delinquencies doesn't -- don't really concern us unless unemployment starts to rise.

But when you look at the Kennedy tax cuts and the Reagan tax cuts, both of those time periods within four quarters of the tax cuts, the economy in those time periods accelerated and, of course, in the Reagan cuts, you remember all the deficits and the concerns about deficits crowding out borrowers and it didn't happen and it doesn't appear to be (INAUDIBLE) today.

So as more people have money to spend as well as corporate, traditionally, again, using the history as a guide, we would suggest we're going to see an accelerated GDP number when this kicks in.

FERRO: Jonathan Golub, before we lose you, Deutsche Bank was on this program 20 minutes ago talking about four rate hikes. We were talking about anticipating a flatter yield curve. What does that mean for financials four rate hike next year, the potential for even flatter yield curve?

GOLUB: If you have four rate hikes that means you have an environment where growth is much stronger and the longer yield curve is coming out. So what -- I don't know what this means to Gerard.

But the conditions that you would have for rate hikes would probably mean that we got much more economic flow through the tax plan. The yield curve is ripping at the long end of the curve and the market may be looking at this thing thinking, "Gosh, things are almost too good."

But the Fed's not doing four rate hikes next year unless conditions are that good.

FERRO: Yes. You agree?

AUTH: I agree completely. (INAUDIBLE)

FERRO: Steve Auth of Federated, great to have you with us. Jonathan Golub of Credit Suisse, thank you. Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek. And to you, of course, Gerard Cassidy joining us on a telephone, thank you very much sir.

FERRO: Mark Yusko, when you think about media, are you thinking more about tech in the same story?

YUSKO: Not that I agree. I think it is that merging of TM&T, (INAUDIBLE) communications is all becoming one big conglomerate.

And these vertical integrations and horizontal expansions I think are going to continue to (INAUDIBLE) right.

FERRO: Steve Auth, looking it more broadly we thought we'd get this big high push up in CEO confidence, it's there. We thought that that would then translate into a more M&A activity. We haven't seen it.

We also thought that this administration would be a light touch on antitrust, we're learning they probably won't be. What does this all mean from consolidation and M&A?

AUTH: I think some of the M&A guidance has been waiting for this tax bill to know the rules they run. So we expect to see quite a bit of M&A going into next year.

On the media front, look, there's value in these big old media companies for sure. We keep sniffing around for that reason. Our problem is we can't quite figure out how this thing gets end up being put together.

There are major cost disadvantage to the big new economy players if you will. We'd rather for now stick with the guys who are winning game, the Facebooks, the Googles, those guys just have a big margin advantage, asset and cash flow advantage for these traditional media companies to sort that.

I think eventually there's going to be something very interesting here but --

FERRO: Just a final question to you, do you think there will be some recognition from antitrust and this administration that these guys aren't competing with themselves anymore, they're competing with Amazon, they're competing with Facebook, et cetera, and this sector is a lot, lot bigger than maybe they thought it was?

TUNA AMOBI, CONSUMER CYCLICAL ANALYST, CFRA RESEARCH: No question this administration is more inclined to a rollback of media regulations that will provide we think a catalyst.

Now, we're a little confused by the kind of the resistance to the AT&T/Time Warner deal. If you kind of take that aside, you see that the bag drop for regulation has become more attractive, things like the reinstatement of the (INAUDIBLE) discount which catalyze (INAUDIBLE) merger.

And I might also add in a long period that we've covered this sector, never before have we seen a conflict of ingredient that we think will kind of provide that next wave of M&A where that is kind of the attractive stock price for media companies, the ample cash reserves, financial flexibility.

And then what we call the Amazon and Netflix factor where companies are trying to anticipate what these two companies are going to do and provide kind of defensive motivation for them to go out and try to mitigate the potential threats from these two companies as another potential catalyst for M&A activity.

So I would argue that this is as good a time as we've ever seen in long time that we've covered this phase for more deals to unfold.

FERRO: Tuna Amobi of CFRA, really appreciate your time this morning sir. Thank you. Steve Auth of Federated and Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek will be sticking with us.

FERRO: Still with us Steve Auth of Federated and Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek. Mark, it must be probably one of the biggest non-stories of this year so far, the changing of the heads at the Federal Reserve because they all look pretty mainstream to me.

YUSKO: Yes. And we're talking about hawks earlier in the year and we got more dove and I don't see a lot changing.

I do a little bit of variant perception on hikes and I actually don't think the hikes are doing anything to restrict liquidity. If you look at financial conditions, they are still very, very loose, in fact, the loosest we've had in a couple decades.

I think what they're trying to do is get back to neutral. See, for a hundred years the Fed fund rate has been equal to nominal GDP which means we really need to be back around three percent.

The problem with getting there is that the yield curve is inverted which probably we need to do a little cleansing but --

FERRO: Steve, biggest challenge for the F1C next year. Just quickly, what is it?

AUTH: I think it's just communicating with the market as we move through here and dealing with maybe a little bit of extra pressure on inflation. But I think they're in a pretty predictable play out, very few rate hikes, more QT and scale back on the regulation?

FERRO: Gents, I really enjoyed your appearance on the show today. Thank you very much for joining us. Steve Auth of Federated. Mark Yusko of Morgan Creek. That does it for us here on the open about 26 minutes into the session.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
