urn:contentItem:5TC7-X7G1-JB20-G13B-00000-00Steve Case Leads Nationwide Effort to Invest in Entrepreneurship; Rod Rosenstein-President Donald Trump Meeting Delayed Until Next Week; Dutch Police for Major Terror Plot in Raids; Gaumard Scientific Creates a Child Robot for Real Life Medical Training; Kavanaugh/Ford Testimony; Body Believed to be Missing Autistic Boy Found; More Problems for Musk2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTSteve Case, Sean Spicer, James Archetto, Dr. Mikhail Varshavski, Gary B. SmithNEWSFinancial092802cb.231Steve Case Leads Nationwide Effort to Invest in Entrepreneurship; Rod Rosenstein-President Donald Trump Meeting Delayed Until Next Week; Dutch Police for Major Terror Plot in Raids; Gaumard Scientific Creates a Child Robot for Real Life Medical Training; Kavanaugh/Ford Testimony; Body Believed to be Missing Autistic Boy Found; More Problems for MuskMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Liz Peek

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning -- everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday. It is Friday, September 28th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Fireworks on Capitol Hill -- the Senate Judiciary Committee set to vote this morning on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. This, after he and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, told their stories yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR PATRICK LEAHY (D-VT), SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Let's go back to the incident. What is the strongest memory you have?

CHRISTINE BLASEY FORD, KAVANAUGH ACCUSER: In the hippocampus is the laughter -- the uproarious laughter between the two and they're having fun at my expense.

JUDGE BRETT KAVANAUGH, SUPREME COURT NOMINEE: My family and my name have been totally and permanently destroyed by vicious and false additional accusations. The 10-day delay has been harmful to me and my family, to the Supreme Court.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More on the fiery testimony in just one minute. And we should tell you that ahead of this vote today, Senator Bob Corker has said he will vote yes for Judge Kavanaugh.

A suit for Musk; the Securities and Exchange Commission charging the Tesla CEO with misleading investors. Tesla is taking a hit in the premarket, stock is down 12.25 percent. Musk's response to the suit coming up.

Markets are lower this morning, take a look. Dow Industrials now at the low of the morning with a decline of about 60 points, that's a quarter of a percent. S&P 500 also down a quarter of a percent, as is the Nasdaq with an 18.5 point decline.

This after all the major indices tacked on gains yesterday, up 54 points on the Dow and the S&P was up eight points, and the Nasdaq at the close, up two-thirds of a percent, 51 points higher.

As we end the near of the second quarter, this is the last trading day of the third quarter. The Dow picked up almost 9 percent. The Nasdaq and the S&P up 7 percent for the third quarter.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the trading performance. FT 100 down 39 points half of a percent. CAC 40 is down three-quarters of a percent and the DAX index down 1.25 percent.

Asian markets this morning finishing mostly in positive territory, best performer Japan. Nikkei average up one and a third percent.

Google is in the hot seat today. The company's CEO is headed to Capitol Hill today for a close door meeting with lawmakers. This, amid charges that the search engine does not treat conservative voices fairly.

And barrels of trouble - why whiskey makers are saying that the trade tensions could put us in a bourbon burden.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining us to break it all down Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, along with Kadina Group president Gary B. Smith, and "The Hill" columnist, Fox News contributor Liz Peek. Great to see everybody this morning.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you.

GARY B. SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUP: Nice to be here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: What a day yesterday. We all watched.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And the question going forward, we were talking about it in the break, what are the consequences of Republicans voting no on Brett Kavanaugh potentially.

To quote Kimberley Strassel's column in the "Wall Street Journal", "The Kavanaugh Stakes". And I'll say this -- if a Republican votes against Brett Kavanaugh you are standing with the sleeze on the left. You're standing by ambush tactics. You're standing by the smears. And it has consequences not just for the man and his family but for the Supreme Court, the Senate, and the country at large.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right. I think this op-ed is so powerful this morning from Kim Strassel. And you're right. She goes through it and she basically says "Any vote no, the stakes go even further to the core of the country's principles. To vote against Kavanaugh is to overthrow due process."

MCDOWELL: Overthrowing due process and essentially sending the message to the country that an individual believes all men are liars and all women are victims. Nobody buys that.

PEEK: Yes. Abandoning the presumption of innocence, which is sort of the bedrock of our judiciary system and everything else. I mean I think it's an appalling approval of character assassination as sort of the first line of defense.

This is all about the complexion of the court changing should Kavanaugh end up on the Supreme Court. It is not about what he did when he was a teenager. It's about basically losing an election in 2016 which allows President Trump to appoint a conservative justice.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly what Lindsey Graham said yesterday. The Senator said exactly what so many people were thinking.

Joining the conversation this morning, White House senior advisor for strategic communications, Mercedes Schlapp is here. Revolution chairman and CEO and former AOL CEO Steve Case is here. Economist Nouriel Roubini will join us. And former White House press secretary under President Trump, Sean Spicer is here as well.

We've got a big two hours coming up. Don't miss a moment of it.

And we kick it off right here -- an emotionally-charged day on Capitol Hill yesterday. Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh publicly testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee over sexual harassment allegations. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FORD: Brett's assault on me drastically altered my life for a very long time. I was too afraid and ashamed to tell anyone these details. It is not my responsibility to determine whether Mr. Kavanaugh deserves to sit on the Supreme Court. My responsibility is to tell you the truth.

LEAHY: Then let's go back to the incident. What is the strongest memory you have?

FORD: Indelible in hippocampus is the laughter -- the uproarious laughter between the two and they're having fun at my expense.

SENATOR DICK DURBIN (D-IL), SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: With what degree of certainty do you believe Brett Kavanaugh assaulted you?

FORD: 100 percent.

KAVANAUGH: I'm here today to tell the truth. I've never sexually assaulted anyone. I intend no ill will to Dr. Ford and her family.

The other night, Ashley and my daughter Liza said their prayers and little Liza, all 10 years old said to Ashley we should pray for the woman -- a lot of wisdom from a 10-year-old.

SENATOR JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA), SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Are Dr. Ford's allegations true?

KAVANAUGH: They're not accurate as to me. I have not questioned that she might have been sexually assaulted at some point in her life by someone, some place, but as to me, I've never done this.

KENNEDY: Do you swear to God?

KAVANAUGH: I swear to God.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This coming as Republican Senator Bob Corker says he will be voting to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. We are waiting on the others and that vote. The committee vote is today at 9:30.

Joining us right now two New York representatives -- Republican Congresswoman Claudia Tenney and Democratic Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney. Congresswomen -- great to see you both. Thank you so much for joining us.

REP. CLAUDIA TENNEY (R), NEW YORK: Thank you.

REP. CAROLYN MALONEY (D), NEW YORK: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Congresswoman Maloney -- I want to begin with you. You waited for Judge Kavanaugh's arrival yesterday with actress Alyssa Milano. Why were you with Alyssa Milano?

MALONEY: I went over to see the hearing. She happened to be there. At first, Senator Feinstein said I had a ticket. And then they moved to a much smaller room. She said I did not have a ticket. There would be four seats for members of Congress and I came very early to make sure that I had one of those seats.

BARTIROMO: She was recording the hearing. Is that against rules?

MALONEY: I really don't know. I did not know she was recording it. But I assume everywhere I go I'm being recorded now on these phones.

BARTIROMO: Yes. She was --

MALONEY: And obviously she didn't have to record it. You recorded it. Everyone recorded it.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Right. You're not supposed to record it from inside the courtroom, you know that, right? You're a congresswoman. She was asked to stop and she did in fact comply.

MALONEY: Well, you should ask her about it. I don't know anything about it.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the hearing yesterday?

MALONEY: Well, I thought it was riveting. And I thought Dr. Ford gave a very sincere, honest, authentic testimony that was tremendously moving. And Brett Kavanaugh also gave a very emotional testimony that was incredibly partisan and attacking against Democrats.

Usually in these confirmation hearings they talk about the law, they talk about working together for the future of the country. It was a partisan attack on -- the most partisan testimony I've ever heard.

BARTIROMO: A partisan testimony on the Democrats' part?

MALONEY: On Judge Kavanaugh's part.

BARTIROMO: Congresswoman Tenney, your thoughts?

TENNEY: Look, I thought they were both very believable. I thought that she seemed to be sincere. But I think this is really important. It comes down to credibility. And I don't think taken as a whole the evidence surrounding what brought her to the hearing in the first place was credible.

I think that she -- if Senator Feinstein really cared about this woman and sexual assault is a very, very serious issue. As a lawyer I have encountered this many times with many of my clients. She would have brought this immediately to law enforcement or the FBI to do an investigation. Instead, they held it.

So all of that moving testimony was really not credible and I respectfully disagree with my colleague who is a terrific member of my committee, this is -- Brett Kavanaugh is under attack. His family is under attack. He was defending himself against some of the worst kind of accusations against a person, dragging him through his high school days, a young man obviously very well accomplished. He's somebody who had a lot of fun but someone who also, you know, was very, very smart, did really well, participated in all kinds of sports and activities.

So I just thought it was a character assassination. I felt that Mr. Kavanaugh or Judge Kavanaugh was right to defend himself and his family.

BARTIROMO: And I know that your father was a New York Supreme Court justice. You were a lawyer who has previously represented sexual assault victims so we wanted to get your take on that.

But I guess what strikes me is, Congresswoman Maloney, is the idea that you say it was this partisan attack and yet Ford remains unable to marshal as Kim Strassel writes, to marshal any evidence for her claim of sexual assault. There was no corroboration whatsoever of her claims of sexual assault. Did you not -- does that not strike you?

MALONEY: Well, first of all --

BARTIROMO: Was there due process in this whole proceeding in your view?

MALONEY: Well, to answer your question, she originally wanted to be anonymous. That's why Senator Feinstein did not call for the FBI investigation in the beginning. But the minute that her identity became public, both Senator Feinstein and Dr. Ford have called for and support an FBI investigation.

There were a number of people there, according to her testimony, interview them. Let's have the FBI get together one set of facts, so that one set of facts are before the committee. And that is I think should be a fundamental -- we shouldn't move forward without an FBI investigation on her points and others.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MALONEY: And I'd like to respond to what my friend and colleague has said about the assault on Brett Kavanaugh. Well, let's look at what she's gained from this. She's got death threats. She's literally had to move her family twice because of death threats. She really hasn't gotten anything out of this except for her belief in wanting integrity in the process for the appointment to the Supreme Court --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MALONEY: -- a lifetime appointment.

BARTIROMO: She obviously truly believes that he was the one that did this to her and obviously whatever she went through is just horrible.

But you mentioned Dianne Feinstein. You know, she said she denied releasing the information from the letter and yet the "Washington Post" got the letter. I mean hers is the only office who had the letter. So it's rich to say, you know, I can't believe that, you know, she wanted to be anonymous and then all of a sudden she's not anonymous. When in fact, yes, she wanted to be anonymous but Feinstein's office sat on the letter for six weeks and then the "Washington Post" suddenly got it.

MALONEY: But she was anonymous in her tip to the "Washington Post". It was the -- it came out -- somehow the press found out and were --

BARTIROMO: Right. Somehow but the only person who had the letter Feinstein's office so how somehow -- the press got it.

MALONEY: Well, I don't know how the press got it.

BARTIROMO: It was leaked.

MALONEY: But I believe that --

BARTIROMO: It was leaked, probably by Feinstein's office.

(CROSSTALK)

MALONEY: -- Feinstein was listening to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's what I'm saying.

Democratic Senator Mazie Hirono's campaign is apologizing this morning. She sent a fund raising e-mail during the Ford testimony, according to published news reports. The message reportedly said the money would be donated to organizations helping survivors of sexual assault. Your thoughts on that -- Congresswoman?

MALONEY: She has apologized. And I accept her apology.

BARTIROMO: This whole idea of throwing due process out the window before anybody's allegations are corroborated -- Congresswoman Tenney, I wonder what your thoughts are in terms of what -- how this is resonating with the people.

TENNEY: Well, I certainly -- it's probably district by district. But I know I'm getting an overwhelming amount of concern on both sides about the process. And I don't disagree with my colleague, Representative Maloney. I think it was a terrible thing for both of these people to go through.

And unfortunately, Dianne Feinstein is the person, obviously you could see by the awkward moment in the testimony yesterday that, they probably did leak the memo and that maybe will come out at some point.

And so unfortunately, both of them were dragged through this process. And I think it was interesting, and you played the clip where Judge Kavanaugh recognized his own daughter feeling sympathy for Dr. Ford. And I did too when I was watching her.

I said as a woman and watching what she had been through -- but again, I go back to the big point is this.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TENNEY: Was she believable? Yes. Was it credible the way this was all put together? Do I believe she was probably a victim? Probably. Do I believe it's Brett Kavanaugh? I don't think so.

And I hate to admit that I also kept calendars when I was in high school and college because I was a very busy student as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TENNEY: So this guy is an accomplished man. He should be confirmed. I think this was a charade. I think Lindsey Graham really highlighted it. I though he was the superstar last night.

BARTIROMO: Yes. There were a lot of funny tactics. I think you would both agree.

Carolyn Maloney --

MALONEY: Thank you.

TENNEY: Well, I think we should have an FBI investigation and get to the facts and then move forward.

BARTIROMO: Congresswoman -- thanks very much for joining us.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Thank you very much for joining us. Both Claudia Tenney, Carolyn Maloney -- great to see you both, ladies. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Heartbreak in North Carolina, a body believed to be the missing six-year- old autistic boy has been found.

Lauren Simonetti with the details -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Tragic story -- Maria.

Search crews discovered the body of a child believed to be that missing autistic boy, Maddox Ritch. His body was found partially submerged in a creek about a mile from where Maddox was reported missing.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERT HELTON, GASTONIA POLICE CHIEF: I'm heartbroken. This is not the end that we had hoped for.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: His father says the six-year-old ran off last Saturday while they were walking together in a park. Investigators are working to find out how the boy died, if there was any foul play involved. That investigation is ongoing.

Well, Audi's CEO reportedly on the verge of losing his job. Volkswagen is Audi's parent company and they're expected to fire Rupert Sadler as early as today. Sadler has been in jail since June over his alleged connections to the diesel emissions cheating scandal that began three years ago.

Shares of Volkswagen -- not a good year them -- they're down about 13 percent.

And you don't have to worry about running out of Kentucky bourbon. An industry trade group says distilleries last year pumped out 7.5 million barrels of aging whiskey. That is the most since 1972. But the good times might be over. An industry leader is warning that trade disputes in key overseas markets could mean global customers start drinking less. I guess then prices go down, right. We'll have more in the market.

Cheers to them.

BARTIROMO: All right. Lauren -- thank you so much.

Coming up -- renewed trouble for Tesla. The stock is down big today. The latest controversy for CEO Elon Musk as the Securities and Exchange Commission files a lawsuit for fraud. That's coming up.

Then, medical training goes high tech. We're checking out the new robot that can bleed, scream and cry -- later this hour.

Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

More turmoil for Tesla -- this is big. The Securities and Exchange Commission is suing Elon Musk for fraud over his tweet about taking the company private at $420, funding secured. The case raising questions about executives using social media to get news out.

Joining me right now is Steve Case. He is the chairman and CEO of Revolution. And he's the former CEO of AOL. Steve -- it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

STEVE CASE, CHAIRMAN & CEO, REVOLUTION: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: We've got a lot happening on Capitol Hill with some of your colleagues in the business, speaking to lawmakers.

But first, let me get your reaction to what's happening with Elon Musk and Tesla with this SEC lawsuit.

CASE: Well Elon is obviously one of the great entrepreneurs of our generation. I have great respect for what he's been building with Tesla and SpaceX and so many other things. But I think -- and I obviously support that CEOs should use social media and the Internet to reach out to customers and other constituencies and, you know, kind of tell their stories.

But I do think there's a number of examples now where maybe Elon, by his own admission, probably should get a little more sleep and probably should be a little more careful before he tweets.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean a lot of discussion this morning about what happens to Tesla if Elon Musk is not there. I mean he's, you know, being sued by the SEC. They're saying we are looking for him to not be able to serve as the CEO of a public company. Your thoughts on Tesla -- can it survive without Elon Musk?

CASE: Well, I'm sure it could. People said could Apple survive without Steve jobs. But clearly, Elon has been a key part of Tesla so hopefully this is a bump in the road and over time they'll resolve this issue and Elon will be able to kind of focus on taking Tesla and some of his other companies to the next level.

BARTIROMO: All right. Steve -- let me switch gears and ask you about Google on Capitol Hill today. Google CEO Sundar Pichai is set to meet with top GOP lawmakers today. You know, that this comes amid growing scrutiny against the company and many social media sites for alleged biased search results, violations of policy, renewed relationship with China as it relates to Google specifically.

I spoke with House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy on Tuesday. He'll be meeting with Pichai today. Here's what he tells me.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: I mean he's committed to coming to a hearing this year, which is a change of where Google has been. I'm concerned because 90 percent of all searches go through Google.

BARTIROMO: Ninety percent.

MCCARTHY: Yes. And 95 percent of everybody drops off by that second page. So that first page matters a lot. Their real concerns are the conservative voices being able to come across. And I think transparency is key.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What about that -- Steve? Google is doing 90 percent of all search.

CASE: Obviously it's been a huge success. We were early supporters when I was running AOL. We did a deal with Google at one point, I own about 5 percent of Google. When it was a little company, it was just, you know, Larry and Sergey and a few other people.

Now it's 100,000 employees and has a huge impact obviously globally, both in terms of how people get information and also being a significant part of the advertising market. It's not surprising therefore that there's more scrutiny, more attention.

I'm glad Google is going to be in Washington today to talk about what they're doing. And think about what the role of these big platforms is. And as I say, it's not surprising that there's more of a backlash against big tech or backlash against Silicon Valley. I predicted it almost three years ago.

I wrote the book, "The Third Wave" because as these platforms become bigger and have more impact and in some cases -- in the face of Facebook maybe even influence the election -- it's not surprising there's nor scrutiny. I think there will be more entrepreneurs in this third wave of the Internet when you're dealing with health care and food and other smart cities.

Policies are going to matter more. Regulations are going to matter more. It's not just about the disruptive entrepreneurs going, you know, focusing on technology in Silicon Valley. It's also engaging in a respectful and responsive way with the policy makers in Washington, Brussels and other places.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's absolutely. And therein lies the problem, right. Because when you were talking about when you were an investor in Google, a small company -- today as you say 100,000 employees, 90 percent of all search results. Do you feel a new tone in terms of the regulatory environment that we could see perhaps calls for this company to be broken up? Or is this sort of the regular way the pendulum swings and you remember what happened with Microsoft, when Microsoft was a real target because of its size and its influence. These companies are more powerful today than ever before.

CASE: They are very powerful. I was part of the whole Microsoft issue when I was running AOL and some of the anti-trust issues. I was even deposed on that trial when the government was basically challenging Microsoft.

At the time, they had something like 95 percent market share in operating systems with Windows and there was a concern by the government which I shared that they were doing some things that were not necessarily, you know, supportive of entrepreneurs and others in the ecosystem in terms of what they wanted to do to innovate.

Ultimately, you know, Microsoft decided to pull back. It was a little bit more careful, kind of self-regulated. And I think I think that is the best approach for these big companies, not just you know, Google but other companies, Facebook and Amazon and so forth.

But if they don't do that, there's no question that there will be more scrutiny. I think there should be more scrutiny because these companies are playing not just a significant role in our lives, and having a significant influence on our economy.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

And now let's look at the AT&TTime Warner merger. Nine state attorneys general are backing AT&T as the Justice Department seeks to reverse the approval of the company's $85.5 billion acquisition of Time Warner. Your take on this deal and its impact.

CASE: Well, obviously I have some history with Time Warner since we merged AOL and Time Warner almost 20 years ago -- 19 years ago. A lot has changed since obviously.

I think the strategic logic of the deal, if they can figure out a way to run it in a more integrated kind of way kind of makes sense. I was a little surprised when the merger closed and then, you know, the government kind of filed this appeal. I think it's better if these things are resolved before things close as opposed to after things close. But we'll see how this stuff plays out.

BARTIROMO: Do you think they should allow this to go through?

CASE: I think they probably should have decided earlier if they really were going to have concerns about it. I think once -- again, I don't know all the details. I've been focusing on working with entrepreneurs in the middle of the country, not on thinking about what Time Warner and AT&T should be doing in Washington, D.C.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let me ask you about that --- Steve.

CASE: But it seems like it should have been resolved earlier.

BARTIROMO: Because you're leading the Rise of the Rest Summit. This is a nationwide an effort to invest in entrepreneurship; help build businesses across the country. This is really an important part of the employment story in our country. Entrepreneurs and small business create the jobs. Tell us more about your effort.

CASE: It's very exciting. We launched this Rise of the Rest initiative over four years ago. But today we're in Chicago. Yesterday we had a hundred entrepreneurs from 50 different cities that are doing amazing things in sectors all across the economy. We brought them together to share perspective. A half a dozen of our investors that are partners, L.P.'s in the Rise of the Rest Fund, including Eric Schmidt, and you know, the venture capitalist Jim Breyer of Silicon Valley, Dan Gilbert from Detroit, Ted Leonsis from D.C., Brad Keywell from here and Chicago. They're all sharing perspectives on scaling companies.

We really believe the next wave of entrepreneurship is not going to just happen on the coast, it's going to happen all across the country. And you said, that's critical. Because the big job creators in our -- in our country are the young, high growth startups. And if we're only backing the startups on the coast -- last year, 75 percent of venture capital went to three states, California, New York and Massachusetts.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

CASE: While the other 47 states fight over 25 percent. So, big states like Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan, get less than one percent.

So, we need to back the entrepreneurs there, creating the jobs there to offset the disruption of technology that's happening on the coast which will continue to happen with A.I., robotics, driverless trucks. They're going to destroy jobs in the middle of the country if we don't offset that at least in part by backing on entrepreneurs in the middle of the country to create jobs in the middle of the country.

That somewhat, some of the challenges we have right now including on the -- on the political front are going to worsen. There are a lot of people in this country -- the majority of the country by some estimates are anxious and fearful of the future. They don't view innovation as a good thing or disruption as a good thing. They view it as a bad thing. It's going to end up potentially destroying their jobs or their communities.

So, we need to make sure we understand that startups play a critical role. We need to level the playing field so everybody, everywhere really has a shot at the American dream. And we're creating jobs all across the country, not just on the coast.

BARTIROMO: You're right. So, you just say three states get the majority of what, private equity?

CASE: 75 percent -- venture capitalist.

BARTIROMO: Venture capital.

CASE: If you look at the venture capital dollars, according to the NBC at a Venture Capital Association last year 75 percent went to just three states. Actually, (INAUDIBLE) they cover --

BARTIROMO: That's amazing.

CASE: 90 percent of the venture capital went to men, less than 10 percent to women.

So, we have some work to do to make sure we're backing every entrepreneur everywhere. That's what Rise the rest is all about, and these hundred entrepreneurs. It's really gratifying and exciting to hear their stories yesterday --

BARTIROMO: Fantastic.

CASE: -- when all these partisanship and all this you know, challenges in the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASE: The entrepreneurs are going to lead the way forward.

BARTIROMO: Love it. Steve Case, good to see you, sir.

CASE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Good Friday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, September 28th. Your top stories right now 07:35 a.m. on the East Coast.

The testimonies are in. Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, testifying on Capitol Hill yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. CHRISTINE BLASEY FORD, BRETT KAVANAUGH'S ACCUSER: The details that -- about that night that bring me here today are the ones I will never forget. They have been seared into my memory and have haunted me episodically as an adult.

JUDGE BRETT KAVANAUGH, ASSOCIATE JUSTICE SUPREME COURT NOMINEE: I swear today under oath before the Senate and the nation, before my family and God, I am innocent of this charge.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The Senate Judiciary Committee set to vote based on their testimonies this morning at 9:30 a.m. So far, we know that Republican Senator Bob Corker has said he will vote to confirm Kavanaugh as did Senator Lindsey Graham.

Futures this morning show the markets will open lower. We are at the lows of the morning right here, Dow Industrials down 90 points, that's a third of a percent. S&P also down a third of a percent, as is the NASDAQ with a decline of 30 points.

These after the major indices finished higher yesterday. As you can see, gains across the board, NASDAQ best performer, up two thirds of a percent yesterday, up 51 points.

As we wrap up the third quarter, the DowIndustrials is up almost nine percent for the quarter. The NASDAQ and the S&P 500 up seven percent for the third quarter. Of course, the fourth quarter begins on Monday.

In Europe this morning, the markets are lower. Take a look. FT-100 down three quarters of one percent. The CAC Quarante is down better than one percent. And the DAX Index is down 1-2/3 percent right now.

Asian markets finished mostly positive with the exception of Korea as you can see.

A terror plot was foiled overseas, we have the incredible footage of police nabbing a group of terror suspects armed with suicide vests and assault rifles.

Plus, recall alert. We've got the details on why Honda is recalling more than 200,000 vehicles. The malfunction that could put you in danger.

And meet HAL, he's the incredible and realistic robot that's helping train the next generation of medical professionals. He'll be here in studio with us in just a few minutes. You've got to meet HAL. Stay with us on that.

But first, the top story this half an hour, meeting postponed. The White House announcing yesterday that President Trump will not be meeting with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein until next week. This as fox is just confirming conservative GOP leaders in the House have reached a deal to bring in Rosenstein for a closed door session meeting to discuss the New York Times story about potentially recording the president and invoking the 25th amendment to remove President Trump. It is not clear, however, if Rosenstein will respond to that congressional request.

Joining us right now is former White House press secretary under President Trump, Senior advisor and spokesperson for America First Action PAC and the author of The Briefing: Politics, the Press, and the President, Sean Spicer. Sean, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

SEAN SPICER, SENIOR ADVISOR AND SPOKESPERSON, AMERICA FIRST ACTION PAC: You bet. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your take on President Trump's meeting with his deputy attorney general?

SPICER: I think it's an important meeting. Obviously you need to make sure that there's a chemistry and relationship and a degree of trust by those you appoint and those are executing important duties throughout your administration. But the president rightly postponed this in light of the other news that's going on with respect to the Supreme Court.

But you know, look, I think that there's a lot about how this thing went down in terms of the reporting of it, whether it was -- whether it happened at all, whether it was a joke, an offended comment that was taken out of context. And I think the president needs to sit down as he's going to do with Mr. Rosenstein and say explain yourself to me, what happened, what did you mean, did it really happen? And there's a lot of extremes that go into that question. Either it really didn't happen or it did happen. And if it did happen, was he joking around and you know, what was the context in which it was said.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because there's more to it, right, Sean? I mean, Rod Rosenstein was the one who signed off on the third FISA warrant to wiretap Carter Page. He wrote a letter to fire Jim Comey and then was upset with the president when the president said that's one of the reasons why he fired him.

And of course, he's been sitting on documents that congress wants to investigate how they came up with this narrative that Trump had anything to do with the Russia meddling.

SPICER: Right. And I think I'll go back to what I said initially Maria, which is, look, these are people that have been appointed by the president of the United States to serve in his administration. He was elected by the American people. And that if these people don't feel comfortable with the policies and agenda that he has, then they have an obligation to resign.

And so, I think the president needs to be able to look in this case Mr. Rosenstein in the eye and say explain yourself to me. If you're not doing what I have asked you to do in terms of the Department of Justice and the actions and policies that I want implemented, then you need to go. You should not be undermining me or opposing this agenda in any way, shape or form. And so, that's a conversation that the two of them need to have.

But as you mentioned, all those aforementioned issues are important and I think we need to make it clear, that these aren't independent agencies that can go do whatever they want. They are appointed to serve and execute the policies and agenda of the president of the United States.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Sean, its Liz Peek. Good morning. It does seem to me that the president is somewhat boxed in. In other words, this has been an incredibly compromising news story about Rosenstein. The question is, if he gets rid of Rosenstein, who is next? I mean, is there a succession possibility here that's going to satisfy supporters of President Trump?

SPICER: Well, I mean, obviously the president selects those individuals. So, I don't know that they have a succession plan in place right now. But I'm sure that there's a ton of qualified individuals either within the department that could be elevated and nominated to that position. Noel Francisco who's the number of the current Solicitor General I think by statute and order would take over certain aspects of the job.

But I think there's a fundamental threshold question that needs to get asked first, which is, you know, whether or not the aspects of this New York Times story were accurate in the first place. So, I'm less worried about the replacement than I am about the nut of the story.

And as I mentioned at the outset, I think there's a big difference between whether it happened at all and then sort of the degrees, if it happened, was its an offhanded joke that is trying to make Mr. Rosenstein look bad in the eyes of the president knowing that something like this might tick him off.

So, I think first and foremost before we start talking about replacements, we need to understand the context of the story and whether or not any of the aspects are true.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point. We want to turn to the House Judiciary Committee. House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte issued a subpoena for the memos related to the former FBI deputy director Andrew McCabe, the so called McCabe memos, writing to attorney general Jeff Sessions this. Given the department's ongoing delays and or refusal to produce these documents, I'm left with no choice but to issue the enclosed subpoena to compel their production.

What effect is this going to have do you think -- we've seen subpoenas before. Are we going to see these memos?

SPICER: Well, I hope so. We're not talking about necessarily putting them in the public domain. But the members have a right, a constitutional right to oversight and the idea that a Republican House is being stymied by a Republican run Department of Justice --

BARTIROMO: Right.

SPICER: -- is mind boggling. So, I don't know why it's taking Chairman Goodlatte to go to the length of a subpoena. They should be able to come to terms privately and meet in closed session, or however -- you know, whatever form is appropriate to review these things. But this is somewhat out of -- out of norm that you have the same party having this discussion. So I think it's -- I would behoove the Department of Justice to work with Chairman Goodlatte and the Republican leadership in the House to satisfy this requests.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Maybe they just don't want to see what's in these memos, right? Because what did Trey Gowdy say Dagen, that it's an embarrassment because we're going to actually see how they came up with this idea that Trump had anything to do with the Russia scandal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: An embarrassment to John Brennan. (INAUDIBLE) And he didn't think that there was anything new in there for the most part. That's not going to be any great shockers in the memos.

SPICER: And the thing -- the other thing that I would add in this is that, for all these people who constantly are crying about transparency, here we have another instance of trying to get more information to understand what's going on and it seems that so many people are actually trying to prevent us from having a greater understanding of what's really going on. For all the people who care about Russia and this collusion.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SPICER: Well, here's another way to find out what's the basis of this, what is that information. We're not -- again, we're not talking about putting it out publicly. It's members of Congress exercising their constitutional responsibility.

BARTIROMO: Right, and this speaks volumes, doesn't it?

SPICER: Right.

BARTIROMO: Sean, thank you so much.

SPICER: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Sean Spicer joining us.

Coming up, a major terror plot was foiled. The developments after police in the Netherlands arrest seven suspects.

Then, a huge recall for Honda to report. Details on the automakers malfunctions software in certain vehicles. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Get this, police in the Netherlands foiling a major terrorist plot. Lauren Simonetti on headlines now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, this as an amazing video and it shows the dramatic moment Maria, when heavily armed Dutch police, check this out, they arrested terrorists suspects in a raid in a parking lot. Authorities say there were seven men who planned to use suicide vests, assault rifles and car bombs targeting at least two locations. Fortunately that attack foiled. About 400 officers took part in a series of raids. There they are. The alleged ring leader of 34 old Iraqi was previously convicted of attempting to travel overseas to join extremist groups.

Well, a recall from Honda this morning, about 232,000 2018 Accords and 2019 Insight hybrid in the U.S. could have a software problem. The rear camera display doesn't work when the cars are put into reverse. Honda says there have been no reports of accidents or injuries related to this potential problem. Shares of the company down 11 percent this year.

And we are getting the first glimpse of Tom Hanks as Mr. Rogers for the upcoming movie about the beloved children's show host. Looks pretty good. The photo Sony has released shows a gray haired hanks in Rogers signature red sweater. That was the sweater he wore on Mr. Rogers neighborhood. The film will follow the story of a reporter who developed an emotional bond with Rogers while profiling him for a magazine. Production started this month. It hits theaters next October. I loved that show growing up, that red sweater, I forgot all about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, me too. Taking the shoes off. Thank you, Lauren. Coming up, talk about a realistic robot. Check this out, we got details on a new machine that can bleed, scream and cry and HAL the robot is in studio. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: The future of medical training may be in the hands of robots. Gaumard Scientific has created HAL, a realistic child robot for medical training that can cry, bleed and react like a real child patient. We have HAL here on the set today.

And joining me right now is Gaumard Scientific corporate planning vice president James Archetto and Dr. Mikhail Varshavski also known as Dr. Mike. Great to see everybody. Thank you so much for joining us.

James, let me start with you. Tell us about HAL and what was the inspiration for creating HAL?

JAMES ARCHETTO, CORPORATE PLANNING VICE PRESIDENT, GAUMARD SCIENTIFIC: HAL is really designed Maria for training physicians, nurses, first responders. What we want is physicians and health care practitioners to really be prepared for those critical situations with patients before they ever get there. So this is a chance for them to really learn a clinically accurate patient.

BARTIROMO: So, how does HAL do that?

ARCHETTO: HAL does that by the combination of electronics, software and hydraulics inside. So you can see his eyes are moving now. He has facial expressions.

And the reason for that, is physicians get a lot of information from that and 5-year-olds don't always talk and don't always provide that information verbally. So, we had to do it in a way with several motors and electronics and software.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Mike, you're a practicing doctor. We're seeing the video of HAL getting blood taken from him.

DR. MIKHAIL VARSHAVSKI, PHYSICIAN, FAMILY MEDICINE: Yes, I mean, when I was training we didn't have simulations this real. We had a basic dummy that didn't move. And you'd be doing chest compressions, he's best you would hear a click to know that you were doing chest compressions in the right way. Here, it sounds like you have the entire picture. You have the emotional feedback. You have visual feedback. You can do procedures on him.

And when you -- I know, you mentioned earlier in one of the segments that you don't want him to look too realistic. Because you were worried about being traumatic to medical students. What was traumatic to me as a medical student was going into my first surgery rotation and not knowing what to do because I didn't have experience on such a high level simulator.

So, having this experience, knowing how to do the procedures, being able to look at a child and seeing it react back and forth with me, that's priceless.

BARTIROMO: How will you react, though? I mean, James, walk us through some of the medical scenarios that HAL can actually replicate.

ARCHETTO: Sure. Let's say that a child goes into respiratory distress, asthmatic on a plain field. For example, playing soccer goes in -- has an asthmatic attack, goes into respiratory distress. HAL will respond appropriately to that. He can actually be intubated to help him breathe. If he goes into cardiac arrest, he can be defibrillated with real energy.

So, as Dr. Mike was describing, those real clinical experiences can take place right here on HAL. And you know, so, I'm controlling him from a tablet here. He's not plugged in. He's completely untethered Maria because accidents take place wherever not always in the hospital.

BARTIROMO: So, this would be helpful to you?

VARSHAVSKI: So, this would be helpful to everybody. Because we're talking about nurses, we're talking about first responders, we're talking about training physicians. And in reality, you never know what to expect in the situations. So, the more simulations you can be put in as a trainee, the better you're going to react when the time comes to make a decision.

Because it's really traumatic in the scene of an injury, in the scene of someone having an asthma attack, your mind starts racing. And if you don't have experience with a simulated patient before that, it makes it really hard to make the right decision.

BARTIROMO: What's the downside risk here, James? I mean, I understand the benefits of having HAL as you very articulately -- as you very articulated it, but is there a downside here? I mean, robots are getting better and better and better.

ARCHETTO: Yes, remember, his objective is training. He's an educational aide to facilitate folks like Dr. Mike in their training experience. So from that standpoint, the objective is to really focus on those clinical experiences.

BARTIROMO: Wow, the hair is really amazing. Look at this. This is great. Great stuff, guys. Thanks very much, James Archetto, Dr. Mike, great -- a pleasure. Thank you, HAL.

ARCHETTO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Really interesting. An education every day.

Still ahead, renewed trouble for Tesla, the latest controversy for CEO Elon Musk after the Securities and Exchange Commission sues him for fraud, that's next hour, right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, September 28th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Time to vote. The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote this morning after the Supreme Court nominee --

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5G1B-DN51-F021-62XS-00000-00Steve Hilton on the lessons he's learnt in Silicon Valley;With a new book and new look, the man who made David Cameron hug a husky, tells Anne McElvoy how living the Californian dream with his Uber-rich wife has made him truly happy - but he misses the Tube2015-05-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisLONDON LIFESteve Hilton on the lessons he's learnt in Silicon ValleyWith a new book and new look, the man who made David Cameron hug a husky, tells Anne McElvoy how living the Californian dream with his Uber-rich wife has made him truly happy - but he misses the Tube

Steve Hilton arrives in the Langham hotel with all the vestiges of the big book tour. A PR lady is nervously keeping his schedule in check. Hilton, true to his form as the man who introduced open-necked shirts to the Conservative tribe, is in hipster orange trousers and a ragged T-shirt, head carefully shorn to highlight blazing blue eyes. If he looks a bit like an off-duty Buddhist monk, Hilton is also a former protégé of ad-man Maurice Saatchi, with a talent for causing a stir.

Promoting his book, More Human: Designing a World in Which People Come First, he's already thrown a cat among the pigeons with his take on the way staid democracies and entrenched power structures block real change: "Regardless of who's in office, the same people are in power. It is a democracy in name only, operating on behalf of a tiny elite no matter the electoral outcome."

You have to wonder how this went down over Sunday lunch at the weekend with his old mate David Cameron at the Prime Minister's constituency home in Oxfordshire in a week when the Tories were congratulating themselves on their election win.

Hilton is one of the old Cameroon inner circle, close to David and Samantha even in his exile in San Francisco, where he has lived since 2012 with his wife, Rachel Whetstone - another former Tory staffer who has just left a senior job at Google to join Uber, the American app-based taxi service. The couple were godparents to the Camerons' late disabled son Ivan, who died in 2009.

"I've known Dave for so long that he knows everything I think so he wouldn't be remotely surprised," Hilton replies, though he adds diplomatically that "Dave is someone who is very human as well as being PM with all that entails."

He did agree to delay publication of the book until after the election, on the grounds that anything he said as a former chief aide (and architect of the 2010 manifesto) could be used against his old friend.

The tome is a well-written, often disarmingly frank scoping of the shortcomings of modern governance and businesses and it reveals Hilton's strength as a mixture of insider and free thinker.

But some might see an irony in the complaints about the perpetuation of elites: "The inhumanity of much modern life, in schools, hospitals and in urban planning, is no concern of the elites because they (we) don't have to experience it. Our children go to private schools, we supplement our NHS care with private insurance and we eat organic food from Waitrose ... for most people though the current system isn't working."

Isn't there just a self-selecting element prominently represented in his old friend's No 10 circle? He chooses his words carefully: "It's a human thing to want to spend time with people you know well."

Hilton's underlying diagnosis sounds a lot more like - dare I say it - gloomy Ed Miliband-ism than David Cameron's  upbeat claim that modern Conservatism can serve all groups well. Hilton replies firmly that the problems of "inhuman" public services are better dealt with by Tory-led innovation and decentralisation (his mantra for addressing overly controlled, people-hostile bureaucracies in health, education and welfare).

Some trenchant criticisms strike a chord, especially on education. He thinks the tyranny of PISA tests and over-centralisation of exam systems is producing school-leavers "fit for the last century, not for the more innovative world we live in".

Occasionally, there are glaring contradictions. He thinks academies and free schools will fix this. I point out that the main concern of academies at the moment is a shift from the established GCSE system to a new scale of grading the year after next that absorbs teachers' efforts and unsettles parents and children to no obviously good end. "That's terrible," says Hilton with feeling. "It isn't the education system I'd design."

The Gove reforms which defined the last government's approach to education get a rather mixed review. "The Soviet comparison is an apt one - using central command to try and run a vast system. Of course you can squeeze some results out of it and muster some sign schools are improving. But is it the big transformation we want to see to prepare for the 21st century? No, and look at the cost to wellbeing and mental health - I don't just mean the children but the parents too - from an over-examined, over-centralised approach?"

He has a particular loathing for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Pisa tests. "Ridiculous. Totally absurd and as damaging for education systems as measuring GDP is for balanced public policy."

He says a new education secretary should "go further in de-centralising and give more powers to head teachers". More striking, he continues to defend the idea of for-profit schools, one of the big reformist ideas that his Tory colleagues have never seriously pursued.

"I never understood how, when if so many businesses can make a profit delivering services and products to state education, you could not take it further and allow for-profit operators to run some schools". He thinks "most people care about good outcomes, not whether something is for-profit or not.

Some Hiltonesque ideas have bitten the dust, notably his brief "Greening" of the Tories. Does he regret that? "For me it was always more about local parks, beaches, countryside and nature - not so much carbon targets and climate change". 

Let us pinch ourselves. He was, after all,  the man who persuaded Cameron to hug a husky before 2010 to highlight his concern about global warming and its effect on the Arctic, which sounds  a strange way to pursue a cleaner beaches drive. I don't get the feeling that the fate of Tory Greenery is his favourite topic.

I wonder how much the thought of Boris in the House as a possible successor to Cameron excites him? Not so much. "I haven't given it much thought".

Related stories

Hilton thinks much of the concentration of power in elites "wouldn't matter so much if everything wasn't run from London, because they'd have competition elsewhere". I wonder if that also applied to the big tech companies, such as Google, criticised for their own brand of high-handedness towards both old media and new entrants? He bristles a bit (the Google spousal loyalty is taking a while to wear off), but admits that disruptive tech companies can end up looking rather more like established corporate hierarchies than is healthy.

I suspect he relies a bit too much on blaming the "bureaucracy" or "the way we run systems overall" for things that elected politicians of whatever stripe could tackle, were they prepared to forego a transient advantage.

He makes the very shrewd point, for instance, that policy reforms often treat people as "abstractions, rather than individuals" and then wonder why they fail to respond to incentives. But that applies in spades to the kind of welfare reform sold on peripheral detail such as the "bedroom tax" on people in large council flats or on limiting the number of children they should have if they make a claim on the state's largesse. It does not exactly sound like the most hands-on, personal approach.

"I think it's an example of an approach where and there is a limit to what that can achieve," he concedes. He thinks more targeted measured, such as identifying troubled families and targeting solutions on them, works better.

These days, Hilton runs Crowdpac, a start-up designed to dilute the power of big donors in the US by informing voters about candidates they might support, reflect their values or preferred campaigns. The relationship between business and government seems to trouble him. "It's not about individual donors, it's about the system that concentrates power," he insists. Wasn't he invited to big donor Tory events in his Number 10 heyday? "I wasn't invited, as I recall".

Between 2010 and 2012 in Downing Street Hilton inspired many, like his protégé and close friend, the entrepreneur Rohan de Silva, who is hosting Hilton's book launch party tonight in Hoxton. Naturally.

Part of the appeal of Hilton, apart from the fertile brain and the boundless energy, was the Boho vibe he brought to the formal Cameron world. Does he miss his W11 life, the days of salon young Tories, and cycling around sockless, puffing on a Marlboro?

We were, I recall, once debarred from the classy environs of an All Bar One because Hilton was deemed unsuitably well dressed to join the better class of after-work lager consumer. I ask if he misses the freewheeling years. He says quite firmly that he doesn't. 

"Everything I do now I owe in some way to Rachel," he says. "She opened up California to me and I've truly never been happier". It sounds more than dutiful to his high-powered wife, currently trying to sort out Uber's regulatory and image issues.

It's the first time he's talked of Whetstone's high-profile move earlier this month from the top table of Google to Uber. "A lot of people would have stayed in the same position and not taken a risk. But Rachel went for a new challenge and I'm so proud of that," he adds."

I wonder how this hyper-achieving family manage to do the ordinary stuff that having two boys aged four and seven demands. "We organise things so that Rachel and I aren't out of town much at the same time and we try to spend weekends together and one of us home for bedtime."

Still, I venture that the couple must spend a lot of time staring at their respective screens. "I don't have a smart phone," he admits. "I didn't have one when I arrived in the US, and somehow life has continued. I teach at Stanford University, I launched a tech company - miraculously, it all seems to work without a phone!"

There must be days, I venture, when he looks at the pool house and villa among the tech-super rich and wonders like the chap in the Talking Heads song Once in a Lifetime, "How did I get here?"

Hilton suddenly looks steely. "I don't really care much about what the top one per cent earn. The gap we ought to care about in wealth is between the middle and the bottom. The problem is the sections of society who feel they are not getting somewhere, not those who do."

He doesn't believe Silicon Valley is overpaid. "Rachel works unbelievably hard and is utterly dedicated to what she does at any time and she's earned everything she has. The tech sector is so fast-changing that no one rests on their laurels. As for me, I'm on the lower rungs, doing something I believe in - so I'm not in the top per cent by a long way".

There are no immediate plans for a return to Blighty. Anything he relishes on returning to his old city? "The Tube!" he enthuses. "A public transport system that works. We haven't got one of those where I live. Fantastic!"

Anne McElvoy is Senior Editor at The Economist

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V0G-R5X1-DXVP-V3TD-00000-00Steve King wants to be Teddy Roosevelt for the internet era;Iowa congressman floats 'breaking up' big tech companies2018-12-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisOPINIONSteve King wants to be Teddy Roosevelt for the internet eraIowa congressman floats 'breaking up' big tech companiesAdam Sullivan

U.S. Rep. Steve King is threatening to use the "Teddy Roosevelt step" against U.S. tech companies.

The Iowa Republican drew national headlines last week for an embarrassing interaction with Google CEO Sundar Pichai at a House Judiciary Committee hearing. King demanded answers after explaining his granddaughter recently was exposed to an attack ad against him while she was playing with a mobile device.

"How does that show up on a 7-year-old's iPhone, who's playing a kids game?" King asked.

"Congressman, iPhone is made by a different company," Pichai explained.

"It might have been an Android," King said.

It was an almost perfect demonstration of the gap in knowledge between those who are frustrated by new technology those who embrace it. King reminded us of friends struggling to explain a non-existent "glitch." My own mother, who is relatively tech savvy, has done the same thing. The difference is she is not trying to write laws.

That scuffle exposed an important point — the people most eager to impose new rules on the tech industry often lack practical knowledge about how technology works.

However, it also shadowed King's more troubling comments. During the hearing, he renewed his pledge to explore a set of overbearing government interventions into private business practices.

King and others are worried that the gatekeepers of digital content are systematically blocking conservative viewpoints. King said Google has a "built-in bias," since its engineers live in liberal California, and the company doesn't monitor their social media accounts for left-wing posts.

How do the tech companies do it? King tried to explain algorithms at another committee hearing this year.

"If a certain word shows up, that sets up a software alarm bell, perhaps connected with another word or two or a phrase, that would cause it automatically to be kicked out. Is that a fair explanation of what goes on?" King asked Google and Facebook staffers in June.

That's not how it works, tech leaders insist, and there are no alarm bells.

Nevertheless, King's preferred remedy is bigger government. He has repeatedly flirted with the idea that the government should treat tech companies as public utilities, mandating open access for all legal purposes.

"Is there any difference in your mind between say, Facebook, and Twitter and YouTube — those, we'll call them utilities, not necessarily public utilities, but utilities — is there any difference between them and, let's say, UPS and FedEx?" King asked conservative media personalities during yet another hearing on the subject this year.

Now King is openly pondering a "Teddy Roosevelt-style break-up," invoking the president who is most remembered for cracking down on large corporations under antimonopoly laws.

The consequences of King's idea would be vast and largely unforeseeable. The internet has thrived under light-touch regulations and, contrary to King's observation, there is ample space for all viewpoints. This kind of talk should make free-market conservatives squeamish.

• Comments: (319) 339-3156; adam.sullivan@thegazette.com

Republican Rep. Steve King talks to voters at the Second Street Emporium restaurant in Webster City, Iowa, U.S. November 5, 2018. REUTERS/Scott Morgan
