Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XW8-6C11-DXH2-6339-00000-00;Steve Mnuchin Weighs In On Impeachment And U.S. Trade Relations; America First Health Policies With Alex Azar; Senator Mike Lee Defends Green Card Giveaway; Rep. Anthony Gonzalez (R-OH) Talks About Introduction of Legislation To Stop World Bank Lending To China; Doug Wead Talks About New Book;2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTSteve Mnuchin, Alex Azar, Jessica Vaughan, Anthony Gonzalez, Doug WeadNEWSFinancial123101cb.229Steve Mnuchin Weighs In On Impeachment And U.S. Trade Relations; America First Health Policies With Alex Azar; Senator Mike Lee Defends Green Card Giveaway; Rep. Anthony Gonzalez (R-OH) Talks About Introduction of Legislation To Stop World Bank Lending To China; Doug Wead Talks About New BookLou Dobbs

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I met a lot of people in my day. I don't recall meeting anybody with such a compelling life -- and life story.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, thanks. It means a lot.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And I so appreciate this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My pleasure.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I am so honored. So honored.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you, buddy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I am so honored by this. Thank you so much.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you so much.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST, LOU DOBBS TONIGHT: Good evening, everybody. President Trump energetically rallying his enthusiastic supporters in Battle Creek, Michigan and around the country for that matter last night while the Democratic Party today did what it has done for the past three years: They stared again into the abyss as both the radical Dems and the leftist media concocted more bizarre and sinister narratives.

Speaker Pelosi declared she would hold up the Articles of Impeachment the Dems had passed, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell today declared Pelosi to be afraid to send those shoddy articles to the Senate.

How did investors and markets react to all of this dire political theater? By moving to new record heights.

In the House of Representatives, in the midst of it all, all the low drama also passed President Trump's USMCA, the new trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, $1.3 trillion worth as a matter of fact.

In the midst of all the political turmoil, the radical Dems' subversion for more than three years, President Trump succeeded in delivering another of his major campaign promises, continuing to balance and make reciprocal U.S. trade.

And with House Speaker Pelosi's decision to delay delivery of those Articles of Impeachment to the Senate and with the House now adjourned for the holidays, there won't be any action until early January.

The President maintaining that the Dems entire process is a hoax, a setup and that the Republicans are now winning because of Pelosi's outright default.

Our next guest has been a key actor in spending negotiations, as well as all of his other duties in his portfolio as Secretary of the Department of Treasury. Joining us tonight is Treasury Secretary, Steven Mnuchin.

Mr. Secretary, great to have you with us. I want to begin first of all, congratulations on the spending package. Secondly, USMCA. Thirdly, and perhaps we could rearrange the order of the China-U.S. Phase 1 deal. It's been a busy week for you, but with your portfolio, I know you're not surprised at what can be done in a week. Great to have you with us.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: Thanks, Lou. It's great to be with you as well. And as you said, it's been a great week for President Trump's economic plan and we couldn't be happier with getting appropriations done.

It's a lot of money for the military, big investment in our military. The President got the Space Force and a lot of wins for the President in this bill.

DOBBS: And the American people -- this has been extraordinary. And I think there is a sizable number of people and even some of them, Trump supporters who are surprised that, well, in modern history to have a President now who actually does what he says he will do, who delivers on campaign promises.

He said he was going to create prosperity for America and for all Americans, and by God, he has done so.

MNUCHIN: Absolutely. He is delivering on all his promises and he is building a great economy for American companies and American workers.

DOBBS: We're hearing a number of wags and you know, a friend of mine used to say every dog has his fleas, detractors, and with USMCA, we're hearing from some quarters that they think that this new deal isn't as good as the old deal. Your reaction when you read that kind of assessment?

MNUCHIN: I think they don't know what they're talking about. This deal is so much better than the old deal. I think this is going to add about 50 basis points of growth to GDP. This has all new types of things, all new types of protections. And I think Ambassador Lighthizer just did a fabulous job negotiating and closing this deal.

DOBBS: And going through all -- I mean, the works out to about $1.3 trillion. It's a larger deal than the than the U.S.-China trade deal that you and Ambassador Lighthizer have been working on for more than a year now. Are you where you think it should be? Is this the deal that the President is going to be satisfied with? Or is it going to take a lot more?

MNUCHIN: No, absolutely. Absolutely. Well, first of all, the USMCA, this has been a major priority for the President in making sure that we bring jobs back to the U.S. and I think this will absolutely accomplish it in making sure that we have great trading relationships with Mexico and Canada.

And on China, as you know, President Trump is the first President who has addressed this issue. This has been an issue both with the Republicans and Democrats, and the President just wants to have a level playing field and I think Phase 1 is an enormous step in the right direction.

We have intellectual property protection, we have financial services that are going to be opened up. We have a currency chapter. We have agricultural structural changes, and this is going to be great for our farmers. They're buying a lot of goods,

DOBBS: And importantly, the enforcement mechanism within this deal. Ambassador Lighthizer, the President, and you have all talked about that importance. How strong is the enforcement mechanism in Phase 1 as it stands now?

MNUCHIN: Well, it's very strong. The enforcement chapter is closed out. So this is the enforcement chapter that is going to be throughout the entire agreement and it is binding. It has a binding mechanism. And again, this is the first time we've ever had an agreement with China on the trade front that has a binding enforcement mechanism.

DOBBS: It strikes me that this President has done something that's -- first of all, it is historic, of course, the historic achievements are -- it's unprecedented. Because this is a President, ahead of the International Monetary Fund, ahead of the World Bank, any other organization in the country in the world, saying we're going to have balanced trade. We're going to have reciprocal trade.

And he has begun now to balance international trading relationships with China, USMCA, and let's not forget the agreement -- the trading agreement - - with Japan and South Korea. I mean, this has been a spectacular demonstration of a man leading all of the major financial institutions, as well as the regulatory and intermediaries around the globe.

MNUCHIN: You're a hundred percent correct, Lou, and the President has been very clear, he wants free trade, but it has got to be free and fair and reciprocal. And in the case of China, our markets had been open to them. Their markets have not been opened us. And this Phase 1 agreement is about rebalancing it.

DOBBS: You use the expression he wants free trade. I once had a discussion with Larry Kudlow on this. I've never heard the President talk about free trade. I've heard him talk about fair and reciprocal trade.

Free trade connotes four decades of failure in terms of managing balances. In terms of reciprocity, it represents 50 years of consecutive trade deficits. I haven't heard the expression, frankly, free trade for months now, perhaps a year or so, until the deal is done and now it's starting to be constructed a bit.

And correct me if I'm wrong, a free trade deal, I think it's more a fair and reciprocal trade deal. Straighten me out.

MNUCHIN: I don't think is this a free trade deal. I think this is a reciprocal trade deal. And, you know, the President has been very clear on reciprocal tariffs and reciprocal trade and balanced trade.

And from the first meeting we had with President Xi and President Trump, President Trump brought this up. He said, we need to have balanced trade. This has to be that it works in both directions and that was acknowledged by President Xi and we've been working on it for two years. We're going to be releasing the agreements soon. I think people will see this is a real agreement with real chapters and real enforcement.

DOBBS: And just a couple of things if I may before we wrap up here and I've just got to again, congratulate you, the President, the administration, and Ambassador Lighthizer. These -- I mean, it's astounding what has been achieved here.

I don't think much of the media is giving you the credit that you deserve because it is historic. It's extraordinary. I want to turn to first though the world's cash, hundred dollar bills, most of it disappearing and unaccounted for. And apparently there's a quest to find out what happened to one -- what is it? $1.5 trillion of $100.00 bills? What's going on?

MNUCHIN: Well, you know, it's interesting. I mean, the dollar is the reserve currency of the world, and everybody wants to hold dollars and the reason why they want to hold dollars is because the U.S. is a safe place to have your money to invest and to hold your assets in U.S. dollars.

And you know, it is interesting because in the world where everything is going digital and electronic payments, the demand for U.S. currency continues to go up. And literally, you know, a lot of these hundred dollar bills are sitting in bank vaults all over the world and particularly in a world of negative interest rates, you know, you can hold U.S. dollars, and you don't have to lose money. So there's a lot of Benjamin's all over the world.

DOBBS: Mr. Secretary, I'm going to do it again. I'm going to congratulate you on just a series of remarkable accomplishments and achievements. And we wish you all the very best as you try to top what has been an extraordinary year this 2019, have an even better 2020.

Steven Mnuchin, Treasury Secretary, thanks for being with us.

MNUCHIN: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next. How the White House is working to bring affordable healthcare to all Americans. Health and Human Services Secretary, Alex Azar joins us right after the break with that a great deal more. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Welcome back. E-cigarette maker, Juul suspending the sale of its fruity e-cigarette flavors. That's right. Fruity e-cigarette flavors ahead of an unexpected U.S. ban.

Juul, will however keep selling its mint, menthol and tobacco flavors. So far 33 people are known to have died in this country from vaping related lung disease.

The CDC says suicides by the way rose 56 percent among young adults and children over the last 10 years. In 2017, suicide was the second leading cause of deaths among people between the age of 10 and 24. In total, 47,000 Americans dying by suicide in 2017.

The Food and Drug Administration setting an all-time record for generic drug approvals for fiscal year 2019. The agency approved more than a thousand generic drugs marking the third straight year of generic drug approvals under the Trump administration, three years of increases.

And joining us now Secretary of Health and Human Services, Alex Azar. Mr. Secretary, great to have you with us. Let's start with the generic drug approvals. I mean, that's a remarkable record. What is driving that?

ALEX AZAR, U.S. SECRETARY OF HEALTH AHD HUMAN SERVICES: Well, it's incredible. It's President Trump's leadership. He told us, approve these generic drugs because competition lowers prices, and the President is adamant about getting drug prices down.

So we've had three years in a row under the President's leadership of historic levels of generic drug approvals, almost 3,000. That means in the first 18 months of the President's term alone, $26 billion of savings to healthcare, and that's going to be the gift that keeps on giving because that competition stays forever.

So he's just -- these changes are causing drug prices to go down. We've seen the biggest decrease in drug prices on the Inflation Index Measure in 51 years. The drug trend when the President took office is down 12 percent since the President took office in terms of where prices would have been.

DOBBS: And the President is adamant, he wants drug prices down. He wants prices for healthcare down. In talking about competition and efficiency, I don't know that we've had a President who has ever talked about introducing the idea of efficiency into healthcare and then achieving results, and certainly in the first term of office.

AZAR: I can assure you he was dogged in getting drug prices down. He wants list prices down. He wants what people pay out of pocket for their drugs down. He wants us to have better negotiations in our Federal programs where we're not getting good deals, and he wants to end foreign free riding. And he has commissioned me to get that done and it's delivering these results.

DOBBS: Foreign free riding. What do you mean by that?

AZAR: The United States overpays for its drugs and our Western high economy competitors underpay for their drugs. Right now, the United States senior citizen is paying for a key class of drugs, these intravenous drugs like for oncology or MS or rheumatoid arthritis, we're paying almost twice what the average Western developed democracy pays.

We are subsidizing socialism. In other countries, they are getting a free ride off of us because we're being chumps and overpaying.

DOBBS: Another example of this President talking about the United States operating as a pansy for the rest of the world.

AZAR: Exactly. When has a President stood up for American seniors like that? To say we're going to stop overpaying and we're going to make the others pay a fair share.

DOBBS: And at this point, this is going to be obviously a central point of the campaign of 2020 because it affects every citizen of this country: Healthcare.

And the Democrats, obviously are moving towards socialism in all aspects by talking about socialized medicine without reservation, Medicare-for-All, they style it. Your thoughts?

AZAR: Medicare-for-All would be Medicare for none. It is really interesting. The same people who presented this utopian vision of Obamacare that it was going to solve all the world's problems, get rid of the uninsured, and everything else, they now admit that Obamacare failed to deliver.

So what have they done, instead of coming to markets and putting the patient at the center? Yet again, a utopian one-size-fits-all vision for the American people of a bureaucratic government takeover of healthcare. And what it's going to do is it's going to undermine Medicare for our seniors.

And what President Trump just a couple of weeks ago said in an Executive Order is, he will be the bulwark. He will defend America's seniors, their Medicare. He will protect it. He will protect what works. He will make it better and he is going to fix what's broken in our system.

DOBBS: There is so much that is broken, particularly when it comes to drugs and no, to me, a more tragic example than the opioid crisis that we see hopefully being resolved here now, but the number of opiate death overdose is extraordinary. Where are we in getting that under control and trying to restore broken lives?

AZAR: Well, you know, thanks to President Trump's leadership, it's a whole government approach and across every single metric, we're winning the battle. We've got a long way to go because it took a while to get into this crisis.

But for the first time in decades, we've seen drug overdose deaths actually decline by five percent. Since the President took office, we've reduced opioid prescribing by 31 percent. We have the opioid overdose reversing drug, a 378 percent increase in prescribing and distribution of that product.

So we're making huge progress and we're getting people in medication- assisted treatment, which is the gold standard for bringing people out of addiction, putting them into work and getting them treated and putting them into long-term recovery that way -- 1.27 million Americans are benefiting from the President's bipartisan leadership there.

DOBBS: So much that is exciting that's happening in healthcare, whether it be immune therapy, targeted therapies that are being developed. The deregulation, if you will, to provide drugs to people at a faster rate than ever before. And deregulation, the effect of those efforts is already showing up. Your thoughts as we conclude here.

AZAR: Well, it is showing results. At HHS, my department, we're one-third of the U.S. government in terms of budget spending. We've delivered last year, $12.6 billion of regulatory savings. That's burden that's relieved on the private sector. This year, it'll be already over $10 billion.

We have cut bureaucracy that has freed up 40 million hours of doctors' time in America to be with patients.

DOBBS: Sure.

AZAR: By getting rid of red tape.

DOBBS: Forty million. I mean, and we're facing a doctor shortage. So this is a timely win.

Mr. Secretary, great talking with you and great work if I may say.

AZAR: Thank you very much.

DOBBS: Thank you so much for all you're doing for the country. We appreciate it. We'll be right back. Please stay with us.

DOBBS: A group of business executives and billionaire donors want Florida's Governor, Ron deSantis to back off his immigration crackdown. The billionaires are lobbying the Governor, lobbying against statewide mandatory e-verify that is to assure that workers are in the country legally and for drivers' licenses for illegal immigrants.

The effort is led by Mike Fernandez, a longtime Jeb Bush donor who supported Hillary Clinton in 2016 and Bob Dickinson, he is a former CEO of Carnival Cruise Line who was accused of replacing American workers with foreign workers, not much came of that and he is still trying.

Senator Mike Lee -- speaking of trying -- is spending his time defending his proposed bill, Senate Bill 386. It is simply an assault on working Americans, the American middle class and by the way, an insult against all Americans because it is duplicitous and deceitful.

The Senate bill is known as -- be ready for this -- the Fairness for High Skilled Immigrants Act. He wrote in a statement Wednesday, quote, "What it does do is end the discriminatory current policy that punishes Green Card applicants from large countries," read China and India.

But that is exactly the problem. It would allow countries like India and China to push through as many H1B visa workers as they like who will then take U.S. jobs at lower pay for an indefinite period, by the way, because they get to automatically stay in the country while they wait for an employer-sponsored application for a Green Card.

And in the 2020 election cycle, here is Senator Lee. He is of course a fan of foreign labor, but not so much American labor. He has raked in thousands from some of the top sponsors of H1B visas -- Microsoft, Google, Amazon, Facebook, -- you know, the usual list.

And joining us tonight is Jessica Vaughan, Director of Policy at the Center for Immigration Studies. Jessica, good to have you with us. 386. Where do you stand on that piece of legislation that is apparently to right great wrongs that have been done to foreign workers in this country?

JESSICA VAUGHAN, DIRECTOR OF POLICY, CENTER FOR IMMIGRATION STUDIES: Oh, it's a terrible piece of legislation and it's very bad for American workers. The main reason it's so bad is because it rewards this business model for employers, and these Indian body shops to replace American workers with foreign workers who come in on visas, and promising them Green Cards, even though they're coming in on temporary work visas. It would put these visa workers at the head of the line to receive Green Cards even faster. And it means that --

DOBBS: But what is the -- I am sorry, Jessica, what is -- but what is the rationale? Why would you want to give 90 percent of the Green Cards to two countries? China? Because that would be the effect.

VAUGHAN: Right? That would be the result. Right. Because of the per country caps meter the issuance of Green Cards, so no one country can monopolize them.

But this legislation would say all of these contract workers from India who replaced American workers would go to the front of the line and that means employers who want to hire talent from the rest of the world would have to get behind them in line. It doesn't solve the backlog problem, because there are something like half a million of these visa workers who feel that they are entitled to get Green Cards, even though they came on a temporary visa.

And it rewards the employers, most of all. I mean, follow the money. That's why the big tech employers are funding this effort is because it allows them to perpetuate the system that has been so harmful for American workers, and costs so many Americans their livelihood, and it's bad for the country to displace this entire sector of tech workers.

DOBBS: I want to ask you, how is it that Mike Lee should be so interested in this backlog? It's a really -- it's one of the most specious pieces of reasoning I've seen by even swamp standards, to suggest that equity is based on a backlog rather than on the nation's needs.

And this will put back President Trump's meritocracy immigration regulation and law for years, if not decades. It may kill it.

VAUGHAN: That's right. Yes, it is a step away from the merit based system that we all know would be the best system for our country. Because most of these workers who came on the H1B visas are not particularly high skilled, they are ordinary workers --

DOBBS: I'm sorry. All these employers and the outsourcers I don't care whether you're talking about the Tata, you're talking about Cognizant, IBM, they tell you that these are the most skilled of all the immigrants in all the world and we've got to have them.

VAUGHAN: It's nonsense. They're ordinary workers doing jobs that Americans once did and they've been hired because they are cheaper.

DOBBS: For lower wage.

VAUGHAN: Right. Exactly. It's all about the paying lower wages and not having to bother with Americans when it bypass U.S. workers. That's how they did it. Follow the money.

You know, as for Senator Lee, you know, I can't speak to his motives, but he does have a lot of these high tech companies in his district and a lot of workers there and you know, it has been billed as fairness --

DOBBS: Well, you know, Utah is a hotbed --

VAUGHAN: Yes.

DOBBS: It's a hotbed of corporate labor arbitrage. I mean, it's preposterous and where is his legislation for the American worker? We took a cursory research run at it. And I will tell you, we found nothing.

He is interested in something quite different than the middle class and the American worker. It's just -- it's stunning to me. And I will never forget, you know, Bill Gates in a chair by himself before Senator Ted Kennedy talking about H1B visas, and how many do you need and he said, an infinite number.

That's what we basically have got isn't it? And the senator called me out for saying that it would double the H1B visas, the effect of that is precisely what I believe it still will do, pushing it to somewhere around 300 well, effectively 300,000. It's far more than that.

What is the estimate of H1B visa holders in this country right now? We're supposed to be giving out 65,000 a year.

VAUGHAN: Oh, it's not 65,000. It's about half a million. Each year, there are probably about 150,000. It's not a capped category because nonprofit organizations can get them in unlimited numbers and that means universities like the University of California under Janet Napolitano replaced all of their American IT workers with visa workers, and this will spread to other industries.

There's no doubt about that to accounting, nursing teaching, many other knowledge professions. Good jobs that Americans now have.

DOBBS: The hospital association in nursing -- a number of the Nurses Associations as I understand also oppose this Senate Bill 386.

VAUGHAN: With good reason. With good reason because -- and it perpetuates and rewards this business model of replacing American workers and --

DOBBS: Yes, which we thought this President was well on the way to eliminating. And then Mike Lee and his own party, this has already moved out of the House, as you know. It is sitting in the Senate for -- it will be one of the most scurrilous acts, in my judgment, against the American worker, particularly under this President, it will not -- it will not be helpful to him in the 2020 election.

This is just -- it's horrific. Jessica, you get the last word.

VAUGHAN: Well, people are expecting the president to do something about this program. The answer is to get rid of the H1B program or drastically reform it so that it's impossible to replace American workers.

Senator Lee threw some other light reforms on it, but it's not enough to end this dysfunctional system and we need to move to a merit-based system.

DOBBS: The President is exactly right, as is his want. Jessica Vaughan, good to have you with us. Thanks so much.

VAUGHAN: Good to talk to you.

DOBBS: Up next, billions of dollars helping China's rise across the globe. Some in Washington want to put an end to that. We'll talk with Congressman Anthony Gonzalez about his efforts to rein in the spending of U.S. tax dollars for China.

The World Bank is a fun place and we'll find out how much fun, when we continue. Stay with us.

DOBBS: A new report finds China tried to get loans from the World Bank to fund civilian surveillance in a province holding more than a million Muslim minorities in retraining camps.

Document showed China's recipients tried to secure tens of thousands of dollars to buy facial recognition and night vision cameras along with other surveillance technology funded by the World Bank.

The World Bank says those funds were not disbursed, which you'll be pleased to know if we can count on that.

Our next guest tonight has introduced legislation to stop World Bank lending to China, at least curb it. Joining us tonight is Congressman Anthony Gonzalez. He is a member of the Financial Services Committee.

Congressman, great to have you with us? Let's start with why in the world is the World Bank sending our taxpayer money to China? Don't we send them enough? Don't they take enough?

REP. ANTHONY GONZALEZ (R-OH): They take enough is the right way to frame it. So you're a hundred percent right. There's no good reason why the United States taxpayer should be backing loans to the Chinese government for prison camps in Xinjiang or for anything, frankly.

But the reason why is because China has infiltrated the World Bank and influenced the World Bank to such a degree that they have severely curbed our influence and theirs has accelerated. They basically bought off the African countries, is my understanding and they also have quite a few allies in Europe. And that's directly at our expense.

And so it's crazy. Anybody who you paint this picture to comes to the same agreement if you're an American, and so I've introduced legislation that will encourage them to do just that, to graduate from the program, never take loans backed by U.S. taxpayers ever again from the World Bank and start to hold them accountable.

DOBBS: Well, good for you. Great for you. And shame on us. I mean, we created the World Bank. We created the International Monetary Fund. And then we act like we are disinterested passive investors. When in point of fact, our attention has never been more required, but what more can we do?

GONZALEZ: Well, I think we've done a lot.

DOBBS: David Malpass is American.

GONZALEZ: Every World Bank President is an American.

DOBBS: Yes, he was -- he's always been a hawk on China. What happened?

GONZALEZ: And he is. So David Malpass is doing a very good job of taming that down. The previous President, Jim Kim was horrific. So China doubled their loan capacity under him. You can look up speeches of the former President touting the Belt and Road Initiative as a positive development for China. And that was under the Obama administration.

When Malpass came in, you start to see the loan program diminish. I want it to go to zero, frankly. I just don't think we should have any dollars there. But he is working hard and his team is. I commend him for that work. But we need to continue to push on this because it's not just going to happen unless we do it.

DOBBS: Well, I want to turn if I may to, to the Articles of Impeachment that are being marked up right now at the House Judiciary Committee. What is your take on why we're even going through this process? Surely, surely, Nancy Pelosi, even Adam Schiff, understand that their farce has exposed them for the louts they are. It's just despicable that they even proceed with this.

GONZALEZ: Yes, I mean, I can tell you back in Northeast Ohio, in my district, this is very unpopular to be going down this impeachment path. You will be hard pressed to find constituents of mine who are excited about the impeachment passed.

And so I'm against it for a whole host of reasons. On principle, I'm against it, but also as I can tell you, in a very important swing district or a very important swing state, the people of Ohio are not for this at all, and I'm with them.

DOBBS: And those are good folks to be with, Congressman. I am with the rest of the country, too, because most of the country is absolutely adamantly opposed to these Articles of Impeachment and carrying out this affront against the President and in fact, everybody who voted for him. It's just unconscionable.

GONZALEZ: Yes, especially so close to the next election. I mean, I'm somebody who believes that whenever you get the opportunity, you put the faith in the American people and you let them decide. That's how self- government works. This close to an election, I think there are a lot of voters, even voters who don't like the President, frankly, who are looking at this and going okay, this feels like a completely partisan exercise and we're about to revolt.

Let the American people decide who the President of the United States is. We're 11 months away.

DOBBS: And yes, and also trying to overthrow a President who is historic in his achievement, his accomplishments and success for the very people of Ohio and every other state in the union. Congressman Anthony Gonzales, thanks for being with us. Come back soon.

GONZALEZ: Thank you. Thanks for having me.

DOBBS: We'll be right back. Stay with us.

DOBBS: The radical Dems attempted overthrow of the Trump presidency started as an effort to first disrupt his campaign, and then to block his path to the White House.

So I've got a few thoughts about all of this, and remind you that once elected, the Dems and the Deep State, together combined to overthrow President Trump.

Perversely, we know all of this because of the investigations that were launched by the F.B.I. and the Justice Department in their efforts to subvert President Trump and his agenda. And the investigations by the D.O.J. Inspector General, his hard work to find out about the -- well, what was going on with those initial investigations, and of course, the dogged determination of Attorney General Barr to investigate the investigators and to begin to hold accountable those who corrupted our government, particularly our F.B.I. and Department of Justice.

Even as we watch the hapless Dems now in the House Judiciary, trying to construct two hollow and meaningless so-called Articles of Impeachment and move them on to the floor of the House, they appear unaware that they've reached well beyond their grasp of the consequences and are now performing before an alert American public.

And after three years of their venomous attacks on President Trump, their broader purpose is all too clear.

The F.B.I.'s Crossfire Hurricane operation, the Special Counsel investigation, the desperately contrived pretext of an Impeachment Inquiry based on one phone call. And now the vapid conclusion to what has been a three-month long farce. All of it is now clear, and all of it was designed to overthrow the President.

If that failed, then to block the President's agenda and at the very least, to intimidate President Trump and his party. The Dems thought the least they could expect from their corrupt scheme was a President who would do their bidding, abandon his wall on the border, be forced to accept illegal immigration, more deadly drugs across our southern border, sign on to any trade agreement that Wall Street and the business roundtable demanded. They were wrong misjudging this president and misjudging the tens of millions of Americans who have stood with him throughout.

In a truly unexpected development, the unity of Republicans standing with President Trump and preserving his presidency and our republic. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: Our next guest has a new book out already, higher on the Amazon bestseller list than the so-called anonymous book. Joining us tonight, a man not anonymous, Doug Wead, adviser to two Presidents, presidential historian, author of the new bestseller, "Inside Trump's White House." It's out today and Doug, congratulations on the book.

We want to tell you we recommend it to you highly, and how much fun was this to write?

DOUG WEAD, PRESIDENTIAL HISTORIAN AND AUTHOR: It was so much fun. You better than anybody would know, it's fun for me to even tell you, but when they finally approved it, and I walk in the Oval Office, he doesn't even say hello, he doesn't shake my hand. I walk in the Oval Office, and he's got these papers and says, this is my private correspondence with Kim Jong- un.

They don't want you to have this. They tell me not to let you see this, but I'm going to let you have it. You can't copy it. You can't keep it, but you can read it. And that's how it started.

DOBBS: That's great. That is wonderful. And very Trumpian, we can say. The origins of the -- first, his motivation to be President. Your thoughts about that? And what you reveal in the book?

WEAD: You know, this was fascinating for me. At one point, we went around and around and I got all the kids to tell me their versions and they were nothing like Bill O'Reilly says it happened to the White House Correspondents' Dinner that none of that it happened. Way before that as you know.

DOBBS: Take that O'Reilly, you're already under the bus there.

WEAD: As you know, because you know him. But he finally at one point, we were talking about business. He said, you know, you buy a business that's poorly run, and then you sell it after you've made it better. You never buy a business that's well run, because you'll lose money.

DOBBS: Yes.

WEAD: He said, I ran for president after two terrible Presidents. So he is thinking Bush and Obama, I'm going to follow them, it's time to run.

DOBBS: Well, he had a great point, because those were two of the worst Presidents, I believe in this country's history, both bumbling. And I know you served one of them, and I don't mean to offend anyone. But the truth is, this country was in terrible shape when the President was elected.

I don't think there are many men or women, I don't think anyone could have done a better job than he has stepping in and doing all that he could against all odds. Your thoughts?

WEAD: Yes, it's remarkable. I think he's a great President. You measure Presidents based on the economy, on how they handle war and peace, on their intelligence, on their communication skills and there's 120 others.

When it comes to communication, he is transformational with digital media. When it comes to intelligence, he could see what the greatest economists in the world couldn't see. They were unanimous, and he was right and they were wrong.

DOBBS: How do you feel about this? Because one of the things that irritates the dickens out of me is to talk about whether he is giving Jerome Powell a deserved tongue lashing because he doesn't have a sense of markets and he raises interest rates.

And people said, well, you know, he had good instincts, as if it was instinctual. No. The man has great judgment. He has great intellect. It's stunning to see the people who do not want to acknowledge the innate capacity of the man, his intelligence, and his judgment.

WEAD: And war and peace. That's what a historian looks for.

DOBBS: Right.

WEAD: It's been 40 years since we've had a President who hasn't started a war -- 40 years. There may be granata or an invasion here like Libya or Bosnia, but they all invaded somebody, not him. And peace and prosperity is the ideal historically for a President.

DOBBS: Absolutely. And to bring home troops as he says he will and as he has, it is a difficult challenge in these times. Your access to the President, how much did you have? In what form?

WEAD: Well, he allowed me to interview anybody I wanted.

DOBBS: That's pretty good access.

WEAD: So I started -- it was pretty good. All the Cabinet -- the hostages, I interviewed the hostages and -- but I started with the family and I couldn't get out of the family. They are so interesting. Jared, nobody really had interviewed Jared extensively. I did.

I've got 600 pages, Lou of transcripts of interviews with the family that are just utterly fascinating.

DOBBS: That's great.

WEAD: And he, the night of the election, he thought he was going to lose early. And they said, what are you going to do? He said, I'm going to go down the stairs, go down on Fifth Avenue, I'm going to say I did my best. I'm a patriot. And then tomorrow, I'm going to get on a plane and go to Ireland and play golf.

And then a few hours later, they returned. They said, you're going to win. You're going to win. And Ivanka was trying to get him away from the TV. He was in the kitchen and he was watching the Clinton -- young ladies crying because Clinton was losing.

He was saying, look at this and imagine how they feel. He was very empathetic for these people. It's very unusual. The story is different than I expected.

DOBBS: Well, and we recommend such stories to you in this terrific bestseller by Doug Wead, "Inside Trump's White House." Fully transparent, giving you great access and we are delighted you wrote the book.

WEAD: And he loves you. I guess, you know that.

DOBBS: Well, you know, it's -- you know, he and I are -- we get along pretty good.

WEAD: You do. You do.

DOBBS: Thanks so much, Doug. Appreciate you being with us tonight. Good night from New York.

urn:contentItem:5XGC-FX01-JCMN-Y24W-00000-00Steve Wozniak joins critics who think Apple Card algorithm might have a major flaw - gender bias2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisSteve Wozniak joins critics who think Apple Card algorithm might have a major flaw - gender biasAndy Meek

Nov 11, 2019( Boy Genius Report: http://bgr.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Over the weekend, one of Apple Card's most high-profile users — who also happens to be none other than Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak — took the dramatic step of joining in the calls from critics who want more government oversight over the algorithms used to make decisions about card users. Case in point: Wozniak said Goldman Sachs, the financial services giant that teamed up with Apple to offer the banking-type services and infrastructure associated with the card, gave Wozniak a 10x Apple Card credit line compared to the one extended to his wife. That's despite the fact that the couple shares various bank and credit card accounts and that other lenders more or less treat them the same for credit purposes.

Woz acknowledged the disparity in a Twitter reply to Ruby on Rails co-creatorDavid Heinemeier Hansson, who on Friday took to Twitter to allege the same thing happening to him: The same thing happened to us. I got 10x the credit limit. We have no separate bank or credit card accounts or any separate assets. Hard to get to a human for a correction though. It's big tech in 2019. — Steve Wozniak (@stevewoz) November 10, 2019[1] Those tweets have, perhaps understandably, not only kicked up a firestorm. But in a statement provided to Bloomberg[2], a spokesman for the New York Department of Financial Services made it clear the department has decided to open an investigation because of this. It would seem to be an investigation into Goldman Sachs, which issues the card, and the statement reads: 'The department will be conducting an investigation to determine whether New York law was violated and ensure all consumers are treated equally regardless of sex.' The spokesman continued: 'Any algorithm that intentionally or not results in discriminatory treatment of women or any other protected class of people violates New York law.' In Hansson's case, he was able to talk to Apple representatives, and it seems his wife's credit line was ultimately bumped up to be equal to his. Still, he continued railing about the experience on Twitter: She spoke to two Apple reps. Both very nice, courteous people representing an utterly broken and reprehensible system. The first person was like 'I don't know why, but I swear we're not discriminating, IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM'. I shit you not. 'IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM!'. — DHH (@dhh) November 8, 2019[3] 'Let's recap here,' Hansson continued in a long Twitter thread. 'Apple offers a credit card that bases its credit assessment on a black-box algorithm that 6 different reps across Apple and (Goldman Sachs) have no visibility into. Even several layers of management. An internal investigation. IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM! 'So nobody understands THE ALGORITHM. Nobody has the power to examine or check THE ALGORITHM. Yet everyone we've talked to from both Apple and GS are SO SURE that THE ALGORITHM isn't biased and discriminating in any way. That's some grade-A management of cognitive dissonance.' Interestingly, this is the second investigation of this kind the New York regulator opened in recent weeks, following another into claims that a UnitedHealth Group Inc. algorithm was biased in favor of white patients over black patients. Apple Card, meanwhile, launched in August as the iPhone maker's first entry into the world of consumer finance and building on the company's existing mobile payment system Apple Pay. Goldman Sachs backs Apple Card, which can be used digitally within Apple Pay as well as in a physical card form. In comments last month, Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon called the introduction of the card 'the most successful credit-card launch ever,' with his company having extended some $10 billion in credit to Apple Card users as of September 30[4]. Image Source: Heikki Saukkomaa/Shutterstock [ 1]: https://twitter.com/stevewoz/status/1193330241478901760?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 2]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-09/viral-tweet-about-apple-card-leads-to-probe-into-goldman-sachs [ 3]:   https://twitter.com/dhh/status/1192945019230945280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 4]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-card-users-received-10-billion-from-goldman-sachs-2019-11

urn:contentItem:5XGC-6F51-DYJW-X0GD-00000-00Steve Wozniak joins critics who think Apple Card algorithm might have a major flaw - gender bias2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexisSteve Wozniak joins critics who think Apple Card algorithm might have a major flaw - gender bias

Over the weekend, one of Apple Card's most high-profile users - who also happens to be none other than Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak - took the dramatic step of joining in the calls from critics who want more government oversight over the algorithms used to make decisions about card users.Case in point: Wozniak said Goldman Sachs, the financial services giant that teamed up with Apple to offer the banking-type services and infrastructure associated with the card, gave Wozniak a 10x Apple Card credit line compared to the one extended to his wife. That's despite the fact that the couple shares various bank and credit card accounts and that other lenders more or less treat them the same for credit purposes.Woz acknowledged the disparity in a Twitter reply to Ruby on Rails co-creator David Heinemeier Hansson, who on Friday took to Twitter to allege the same thing happening to him:The same thing happened to us. I got 10x the credit limit. We have no separate bank or credit card accounts or any separate assets. Hard to get to a human for a correction though. It's big tech in 2019.- Steve Wozniak (@stevewoz) November 10, 2019

Those tweets have, perhaps understandably, not only kicked up a firestorm. But in a statement provided to Bloomberg, a spokesman for the New York Department of Financial Services made it clear the department has decided to open an investigation because of this. It would seem to be an investigation into Goldman Sachs, which issues the card, and the statement reads: "The department will be conducting an investigation to determine whether New York law was violated and ensure all consumers are treated equally regardless of sex."

The spokesman continued: "Any algorithm that intentionally or not results in discriminatory treatment of women or any other protected class of people violates New York law."

In Hansson's case, he was able to talk to Apple representatives, and it seems his wife's credit line was ultimately bumped up to be equal to his. Still, he continued railing about the experience on Twitter:

She spoke to two Apple reps. Both very nice, courteous people representing an utterly broken and reprehensible system. The first person was like "I don't know why, but I swear we're not discriminating, IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM". I shit you not. "IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM!".

- DHH (@dhh) November 8, 2019

"Let's recap here," Hansson continued in a long Twitter thread. "Apple offers a credit card that bases its credit assessment on a black-box algorithm that 6 different reps across Apple and (Goldman Sachs) have no visibility into. Even several layers of management. An internal investigation. IT'S JUST THE ALGORITHM!

"So nobody understands THE ALGORITHM. Nobody has the power to examine or check THE ALGORITHM. Yet everyone we've talked to from both Apple and GS are SO SURE that THE ALGORITHM isn't biased and discriminating in any way. That's some grade-A management of cognitive dissonance."

Interestingly, this is the second investigation of this kind the New York regulator opened in recent weeks, following another into claims that a UnitedHealth Group Inc. algorithm was biased in favor of white patients over black patients.

Apple Card, meanwhile, launched in August as the iPhone maker's first entry into the world of consumer finance and building on the company's existing mobile payment system Apple Pay. Goldman Sachs backs Apple Card, which can be used digitally within Apple Pay as well as in a physical card form. In comments last month, Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon called the introduction of the card "the most successful credit-card launch ever," with his company having extended some $10 billion in credit to Apple Card users as of September 30.

More from BGR

Apple credit card partner calls Apple Card the 'most successful' launch ever   Please, for the love of God, shut up about the Apple Card getting ruined by leather and denim   Apple Card is available beginning right now for all iPhone users in the US

urn:contentItem:5HSM-Y0C1-F03R-N3F8-00000-00[Stewart Baker] Time to get serious about Europe's sabotage of US terror intelligence programs.2016-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:01ZLexisNexis[Stewart Baker] Time to get serious about Europe's sabotage of US terror intelligence programs.Stewart Baker

Jan 05, 2016( The Volokh Conspiracy: http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> The intelligence tools that protect us from terrorism are under attack, and from an unlikely quarter. Europe, which depends on America's intelligence reach to fend off terrorists, has embarked on a path that will sabotage some of our most important intelligence capabilities. This crisis has been a long time brewing, and up to now, the US has responded with a patchwork of stopgap half-solutions.

That's not likely to work this time. We need a new strategy. And most of all, we need to get serious about defending U.S. interests. It's no surprise that the US fight against terrorism depends crucially on the so-called 702 program, which allows the government to serve orders on social media, webmail, and electronic service providers who store their global customers' data in the United States. The intelligence we gather in this way protects Europe as much as the United States. Within days of the Paris attacks, the US agreed to give France direct access to much raw intelligence[1]. Even more recently, the German government credited US (and French) intelligence with helping it thwart[2] planned suicide bombings in Munich over the New Year holiday. The British communications intelligence agency, GCHQ, has a deeply integrated intelligence sharing arrangement with NSA[3]. None of these countries, let alone the smaller members of the European Union, can hope to match the American intelligence resources that are now marshaled in their defense. So it might seem odd that the European Union poses a threat to these capabilities. Odd but true. The problem has deep roots in Europe's dysfunctional governance structure and in the mix of dependence and resentment that shape its relationship to the United States. In the name of protecting privacy, the EU has long insisted that personal data may not be exported to other countries unless those countries provide 'adequate' legal guarantees for privacy[4], and it has frequently threatened to cut off data flows to the United States because of differences in US and EU data protection law. The threats were grounded partly in economic interest - keeping data processing jobs and companies in Europe - and partly in a European enthusiasm for expressing its moral superiority to the United States. The EU and US have always been able to negotiate a solution as these crises have been created, but the dynamic changed this fall when the European Court of Justice (ECJ) was asked to rule on the adequacy of US privacy law. Relying in part on irresponsible and inaccurate statements by the European Commission, the ECJ declared that the Commission had not justified a conclusion that United States surveillance oversight is 'adequate[5].' It overturned the 'Safe Harbor' that had allowed US companies to send customer data across the Atlantic. Just as important, it authorized individual data protection agencies in each member state to adjudicate the lawfulness of data transfers to the United States. While the decisions of those agencies can be appealed, the EU has reached agreement on penalties for data protection violations[6] that are a percentage of companies' global revenue - billions of dollars in the case of big tech companies like Google and Microsoft. With those penalties hanging over their head, few companies will want to gamble that they'll be vindicated on appeal. The data protection agencies, meanwhile, are delighted to have the US and its tech companies in their sights; they've said that enforcement actions are likely to begin at the end of January.[7] The European Commission has been trying to reach a new agreement with the United States to reinstate the Safe Harbor;[8] the US has provided assurances that our intelligence oversight meets European standards. (Indeed, it far exceeds anything that French or German or British intelligence agencies put up with.) But the Commission's authority to bind the data protection authorities is in doubt, and it is increasingly under the thumb of a reflexively anti-American European Parliament, which will be inclined to reject or cavil at whatever it negotiates. As a result, the Commission has dug in its heels, demanding wide access to (and implicit authority over) US intelligence programs. There's a high probability that no deal, or at least no good deal, can be reached with the Commission. Weirdly, the European institutions that have created this mess have no serious responsibility for stopping terrorism or for collecting and using intelligence. The European security agencies that have that responsibility are powerful in individual countries but have little sway in Brussels. This means that the machinery set in motion by the European Court of Justice will grind forward, with everyone doing what they've done before: The Commission will seek maximum concessions from US intelligence agencies. The European Parliament will deem the concessions insufficient. The data protection agencies will do all they can to punish American tech companies. Without a deal, tech companies may have to move their data centers out of the United States - making counterterrorism intelligence unavailable to our government. And they will be under heavy pressure to break with the US government on intelligence issues - to encrypt even more data to foil US intercepts, and to fight US intelligence orders in court and in Congress. US intelligence will suffer, perhaps greatly, and European and Americans will be at greater risk of terrorist attacks. In short, if all the players in this drama just keep doing what they've always done, the result will be a disaster for US (and European) counterterrorism efforts. If we want to stave off that disaster, we have to shake up the peculiar European structures that are driving this outcome. We have to make clear that continued attempts to hold American companies hostage over intelligence collection is simply unacceptable to the United States. Up to now, the Administration has tried to appease Europe; it has not played hard ball. And Congress has been disappointingly inactive, except for the House of Representatives, which has gone from inactive to supine in a related dispute, proposing to amend US law to give greater privacy rights to Europeans without demanding even before the negotiations are complete[9]. What could the US do to change Europe's negotiating calculus? It's not that hard, if we have the will. Congress (or, frankly, the President) could simply prohibit the sharing of intelligence with any country whose data protection agencies take action that has the effect of undermining US intelligence capabilities; this would certainly include punishing private companies that send data to the United States. Such a measure would make clear the connection between European data protectionism and our lost counterterrorism insights. While it is harsh to cut off intelligence to countries that are often allies against terrorism, the fact is that their policies will slowly cut off US access to terrorism intelligence. (We don't have to cut off access across the board; the measure could allow exceptions when the President certifies the need to share particular intelligence, but broad intelligence sharing would be barred with any country that takes action against US data access.) Such a measure has the advantage of putting the onus of solving the problem on individual member states - the entities responsible for national security and for the actions of the data protection agencies. (It's notable that data protection authorities have rarely or never tried to regulate their own national intelligence agencies; they don't have the clout. Which strongly suggests that those agencies can bring the data protectors to heel if their access to US intelligence depends on it.) Negotiations with individual European nations, then, are far more likely to produce responsible results than negotiations with the neutered European Commission. That's one way of making clear to Europe that we've had enough. Here's another. The US and Europe have been negotiating a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership for years, and it's likely that a deal will be presented to Congress for approval in 2016. This is part of the Obama administration's ambitious effort to lock in a host of environmental, intellectual property, labor and trade policies via large multinational deals. You'd think that any effort to restrict protectionism and foster trade would address Europe's data export restraints - probably the biggest trade issue between the US and the EU in the last fifteen years. You'd be wrong. Both the European Commission and the European Parliament have taken data protectionism off the table in this trade deal, insisting that their current rules must be untouched. The result is a trade deal that as a practical matter blesses the current EU attack on our counterterrorism intelligence programs. Unlike the European Parliament, Congress has said nothing about the issue, strengthening the European hand. Yet it is Europe that likely needs a trade deal far more than the US. Europe's economy has lagged ours in growth and employment for decades, with the one economic bright spot being a consistently large trade surplus with the US. Congress should take a page from the European Parliament's book, adopting a resolution stating that no transatlantic trade deal will be approved if it permits the EU's current interference with both US technology trade and US counterterrorism capabilities. There will be opposition to either of these measures. Many American businesses expect to get specific benefits from a trade deal, and they are reluctant to upset the apple cart. Refusing to share terror intelligence, meanwhile, has a cold-hearted air. But if we fail to deal with Europe's data protectionism in this trade deal, we may never have another chance; that will be bad for US industry, which will increasingly be held hostage or forced to accept uneconomic restrictions on how they manage their data. And cutting off counterterrorism intelligence sharing with countries that are undermining the foundation on which that intelligence rests is simply a matter of self-preservation. If Europe wants to cripple its intelligence agencies, it is free to make that choice. We should not let it cripple ours. <nl/> http://rc.feedsportal.com/r/247387149090/u/0/f/669424/c/34656/s/4ca7cdb0/sc/24/rc/1/rc.htm<nl/>http://rc.feedsportal.com/r/247387149090/u/0/f/669424/c/34656/s/4ca7cdb0/sc/24/rc/2/rc.htm<nl/>http://rc.feedsportal.com/r/247387149090/u/0/f/669424/c/34656/s/4ca7cdb0/sc/24/rc/3/rc.htm<nl/>http://da.feedsportal.com/r/247387149090/u/0/f/669424/c/34656/s/4ca7cdb0/sc/24/a2.htm   http://adchoice.feedsportal.com/r/247387149090/u/0/f/669424/c/34656/s/4ca7cdb0/sc/24/ach.htm   http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/volokh/mainfeed?a=x0JutCFjB6I:3fS0gzmpAKo:yIl2AUoC8zA   http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/volokh/mainfeed?a=x0JutCFjB6I:3fS0gzmpAKo:qj6IDK7rITs<nl/> [ 1]:   https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/1428 [ 2]:   http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/31/munich-police-warn-of-imminent-threat-of-terror-attack [ 3]:   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Communications_Headquarters [ 4]:   http://ec.europa.eu/justice/policies/privacy/docs/international_transfers_faq/international_transfers_faq.pdf [ 5]:   http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?docid=169195...lang=EN [ 6]:   http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6321_en.htm [ 7]:   http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/article-29/press-material/press-release/art29_press_material/2015/20151016_wp29_statement_on_schrems_judgement.pdf [ 8]:   http://blogs.wsj.com/brussels/2015/11/12/eu-justice-chief-vera-jourova-speaks-on-negotiating-new-safe-harbor-pact-with-u-s/ [ 9]:   https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/1428
